description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The 70-697 Configuring Windows Devices exam covers topics that are a “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows desktops and other devices in a corporate or enterprise environment. Most people know how to use Windows in a home environment, but there are many features under the hood that are designed for environments with a large quantity of computers. The MCSA dives into those and gives the viewer a whole new toolbox for ensuring their computing environment is functional and stable.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike demonstrate using a Microsoft account to synchronize settings across multiple devices. They also look at how to disable this functionality using Group Policy. Then they demonstrate how to assign an Office 365 license to a user.
episodes.title: Support Microsoft Store and Cloud Apps

You hover over it'll tell you what it is.

459
00:24:15.682 --> 00:24:19.240
There's pin, so
if I want to use my pin to log in,

460
00:24:19.240 --> 00:24:22.400
which I haven't shown you how to set up,
we will in another episode.

461
00:24:22.400 --> 00:24:27.080
I can use my password to log in,
which is what it's set to currently.

462
00:24:27.080 --> 00:24:30.100
That's why that particular
box has got that grey border,

463
00:24:30.100 --> 00:24:33.580
that lighter grey border around it,
or I can switch to fingerprint.

464
00:24:33.580 --> 00:24:36.670
And if I hadn't turned off
the facial recognition,

465
00:24:36.670 --> 00:24:39.040
the camera option would
be showing here as well.

466
00:24:39.040 --> 00:24:40.940
But if I wanna use my
fingerprint to sign in,

467
00:24:40.940 --> 00:24:43.970
I simply click fingerprint,
I can say that.

468
00:24:43.970 --> 00:24:48.030
And then again,
run my finger over the scanner, and

469
00:24:48.030 --> 00:24:51.140
sure enough I'm logged right back in.

470
00:24:51.140 --> 00:24:52.500
And the cool thing is, it remembers.

471
00:24:52.500 --> 00:25:00.210
So, if I log off now And
I go to log back into my system.

472
00:25:00.210 --> 00:25:03.750
Notice it says, to sign in, scan your
finger across the fingerprint reader.

473
00:25:03.750 --> 00:25:06.680
So you don't have to go to that
every time, and choose, hey,

474
00:25:06.680 --> 00:25:09.020
I wanna use my fingerprint, hey,
I wanna use my fingerprint.

475
00:25:09.020 --> 00:25:11.090
Or hey, I wanna use facial recognition.

476
00:25:11.090 --> 00:25:16.310
It remembers the one you used last, and
it will bring that one up as the default.

477
00:25:16.310 --> 00:25:20.160
Now, let's say I had used
the fingerprint to login for

478
00:25:20.160 --> 00:25:23.040
the last week, but
I cut my finger really bad.

479
00:25:23.040 --> 00:25:26.105
And I only set up one finger, and
it's not recognizing my finger anymore,

480
00:25:26.105 --> 00:25:27.760
because of that cut.

481
00:25:27.760 --> 00:25:29.440
Now I can't get in into my system?

482
00:25:29.440 --> 00:25:31.930
No, I can simply go to sign in options,
and

483
00:25:31.930 --> 00:25:36.970
I can switch it back to password, or
PIN, and I can authenticate that way.

484
00:25:36.970 --> 00:25:39.940
So you can always change what
it's using to authenticate.

485
00:25:39.940 --> 00:25:43.945
But understand, it remembers or
uses the last method that you used.

486
00:25:43.945 --> 00:25:48.270
Also keep in mind that, this does
not go with you to other machines.

487
00:25:48.270 --> 00:25:52.034
So if you set those up on this laptop,
and you got a desktop at home,

488
00:25:52.034 --> 00:25:56.290
you'd have to have the hardware,
the fingerprint scanner, the camera.

489
00:25:56.290 --> 00:26:00.530
And you'd have to set up that on that
machine as well, it's all stored Locally.

490
00:26:00.530 --> 00:26:03.710
And Cherokee, I think that pretty
much covers Windows Hello and

491
00:26:03.710 --> 00:26:05.680
Biometrics, in Windows 10.

492
00:26:05.680 --> 00:26:09.412
>> Well I know what I'll be asking Don for
now, thank you so much Mike,

493
00:26:09.412 --> 00:26:13.030
and thank you for joining us as well,
but for now let's sign out.

494
00:26:13.030 --> 00:26:14.490
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

495
00:26:14.490 --> 00:26:18.350
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick,
>> See you next time here at ITPRO TV

496
00:26:18.350 --> 00:26:24.818
[MUSIC]

497
00:26:24.818 --> 00:26:27.849
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike continue their look at authentication and authorization. They demonstrate creating and using and virtual smart cards. They also look at configuring Homegroups.
episodes.title: Support Authentication and Authorization Pt3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:05.305
Welcome to ITPROTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:05.305 --> 00:00:07.794
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.794 --> 00:00:08.491
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.491 --> 00:00:12.020
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

5
00:00:12.020 --> 00:00:15.470
>> Welcome everyone to your
Configuring Windows Devices series,

6
00:00:15.470 --> 00:00:19.540
especially if you're studying for
that 70-697 exam.

7
00:00:19.540 --> 00:00:21.350
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:21.350 --> 00:00:25.000
In this episode we'll continue to
taking a look at how we can support

9
00:00:25.000 --> 00:00:27.330
authentication and authorization.

10
00:00:27.330 --> 00:00:30.310
And with us today in studio,
we have Mr. Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:30.310 --> 00:00:31.380
How is it going today, Mike?

12
00:00:31.380 --> 00:00:32.320
>> It's going great Cherokee.

13
00:00:32.320 --> 00:00:33.170
Thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:33.170 --> 00:00:34.860
>> Of course.
>> We've got a little bit more to talk

15
00:00:34.860 --> 00:00:36.490
about when it comes to good old

16
00:00:36.490 --> 00:00:38.750
authentication authorization
in Windows 10.

17
00:00:38.750 --> 00:00:42.350
On our previous episodes,
we took at look at certificates and

18
00:00:42.350 --> 00:00:44.670
how we can use those,
and troubleshoot those.

19
00:00:44.670 --> 00:00:47.820
We also looked at some of the new
biometric capabilities within Windows 10.

20
00:00:47.820 --> 00:00:51.700
We looked at using a fingerprint scanner,
as well as using one of those new,

21
00:00:51.700 --> 00:00:54.210
fancy IR cameras do some
facial recognition.

22
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:54.750
>> That was fun.

23
00:00:54.750 --> 00:00:56.682
[LAUGH]
>> That was pretty exciting, wasn't it?

24
00:00:56.682 --> 00:00:58.890
All right, and so
continuing along that thought process,

25
00:00:58.890 --> 00:01:03.310
we're next gonna talk about something
known as virtual smart cards.

26
00:01:03.310 --> 00:01:07.340
And most of you are probably familiar
with the concept of a smart card, but

27
00:01:07.340 --> 00:01:10.570
let's make sure we review,
just make sure we're all on the same page.

28
00:01:10.570 --> 00:01:11.540
When we talk about a smart card,

29
00:01:11.540 --> 00:01:15.820
we're talking about a credit card-like
device that has a little chip on it.

30
00:01:15.820 --> 00:01:19.920
And we can store information in there,
typically a certificate, right?

31
00:01:19.920 --> 00:01:22.790
We talked about a certificate,
an electronic document

32
00:01:22.790 --> 00:01:27.040
that ties your identity to a key pair and
you can use to identify yourself, right?

33
00:01:27.040 --> 00:01:31.560
If we have a smart card reader plugged
into our system or a system that has

34
00:01:31.560 --> 00:01:34.790
a smart card reader built in to it,
or I can insert that smart card.

35
00:01:34.790 --> 00:01:37.690
We can use that for
identification purposes.

36
00:01:37.690 --> 00:01:39.630
>> Now Mike you talked
about this in another show,

37
00:01:39.630 --> 00:01:43.960
some reasons why smart cards aren't
always the best solution, like cost.

38
00:01:43.960 --> 00:01:47.040
And then if someone were to go ahead and
lose their smart card,

39
00:01:47.040 --> 00:01:48.630
how do we handle that situation?

40
00:01:48.630 --> 00:01:53.310
So would this be, would you say, a better
alternative to these types of issues?

41
00:01:53.310 --> 00:01:55.540
>> It can definitely help
with both of those, right?

42
00:01:55.540 --> 00:01:58.290
Because all of those
are definitely some issues we have

43
00:01:58.290 --> 00:01:59.740
with using traditional smart cards.

44
00:01:59.740 --> 00:02:03.980
We've got the expense of the equipment,
you don't have to buy external readers or

45
00:02:03.980 --> 00:02:07.630
I have to make sure I buy devices
that have readers built into them.

46
00:02:07.630 --> 00:02:11.110
I've gotta buy the cards themselves,
I've gotta buy the equipment or

47
00:02:11.110 --> 00:02:15.113
pay somebody to load the information onto
the smart cards like the certificates.

48
00:02:15.113 --> 00:02:19.100
And then exactly like you said Cherokee,
if that user leaves their certificate or

49
00:02:19.100 --> 00:02:21.210
smart card at home how do I authenticate?

50
00:02:21.210 --> 00:02:25.140
Do we have it set up where they can use
either the smart card or the password?

51
00:02:25.140 --> 00:02:27.850
Isn't that reducing our security overall?

52
00:02:27.850 --> 00:02:31.310
Or do we say, hey, you can't log in,
and you have to go home for the day?

53
00:02:31.310 --> 00:02:34.540
Do we have to reissue cards and
delete the old card,

54
00:02:34.540 --> 00:02:37.240
or invalidate the old card, revoke it?

55
00:02:37.240 --> 00:02:38.970
There are some issues there.

56
00:02:38.970 --> 00:02:42.100
Virtual smart cards are the same concept,
right?

57
00:02:42.100 --> 00:02:46.350
We're gonna have a smart card that we're
gonna load a certificate on that I can use

58
00:02:46.350 --> 00:02:49.590
for authentication purposes
amongst other things.

59
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:52.750
But it's virtual,
it's not a physical thing.

60
00:02:52.750 --> 00:02:58.500
It actually get stored in something known
as the TPM or the Trusted Platform Module.

61
00:02:58.500 --> 00:03:01.150
Which is a special chip
on your motherboard

62
00:03:01.150 --> 00:03:04.270
that's isolated from everything else and
very secure.

63
00:03:04.270 --> 00:03:05.970
Most of our modern motherboards,

64
00:03:05.970 --> 00:03:08.680
most of your modern computers
are gonna come with a TPM.

65
00:03:08.680 --> 00:03:12.200
This isn't something you can go out and
buy and add on.

66
00:03:12.200 --> 00:03:14.230
It is soldered onto the motherboard.

67
00:03:14.230 --> 00:03:18.460
It's not exportable, I can't take
that TPM out of one computer and

68
00:03:18.460 --> 00:03:20.660
put it in another computer.

69
00:03:20.660 --> 00:03:23.600
So it's not something that I can
transfer or anything like that.

70
00:03:23.600 --> 00:03:26.510
I do have to make sure I have
a system that has a TPM built in.

71
00:03:26.510 --> 00:03:29.855
>> Now, Mike, I know I've had issues
before where I actually had to

72
00:03:29.855 --> 00:03:33.075
update my TPM, so are there different
versions that we need to be aware of

73
00:03:33.075 --> 00:03:34.657
when we're using this technology?

74
00:03:34.657 --> 00:03:36.765
>> There are,
as far as the operating system goes.

75
00:03:36.765 --> 00:03:39.865
Windows started supporting
this back in Windows 8.1, so

76
00:03:39.865 --> 00:03:42.337
8.1 and later, you'll be good to go.

77
00:03:42.337 --> 00:03:47.337
You do need a TPM, a trusted platform
module version 1.2 or higher.

78
00:03:47.337 --> 00:03:51.017
I think 1.2 is the latest at
the time of this shooting.

79
00:03:51.017 --> 00:03:53.257
But 1.2 or higher, should be good to go.

80
00:03:53.257 --> 00:03:56.717
There's also a limit of ten
virtual smart-cards per computer.

81
00:03:56.717 --> 00:03:59.947
Now be careful with that one,
that's a great exam question.

82
00:03:59.947 --> 00:04:02.870
It's not per user, it's per computer.

83
00:04:02.870 --> 00:04:06.660
I could have ten virtual smart cards
myself from my one account, or

84
00:04:06.660 --> 00:04:10.130
it could be a scenario where I share
this computer with other people and

85
00:04:10.130 --> 00:04:12.690
each of us has our our own virtual
smart card loaded in the TPM.

86
00:04:12.690 --> 00:04:16.700
But it's a total of ten virtual
smart cards on that machine,

87
00:04:16.700 --> 00:04:19.795
not on a per user basis.

88
00:04:19.795 --> 00:04:22.967
[CROSSTALK]
>> This might be a silly question but

89
00:04:22.967 --> 00:04:24.744
what would I do with ten smart cards.

90
00:04:24.744 --> 00:04:27.130
>> [LAUGH] That's actually
a decent question.

91
00:04:27.130 --> 00:04:30.170
I'm gonna play poker with them and
throw away my worst two and

92
00:04:30.170 --> 00:04:31.660
get my next best two.

93
00:04:31.660 --> 00:04:34.700
No, you might have more than one for
different purposes, right?

94
00:04:34.700 --> 00:04:37.170
Remember, certificates,
those electronic documents,

95
00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:41.020
can be issued by a certificate
authority for varying purposes.

96
00:04:41.020 --> 00:04:44.200
Sometimes those certificates
can be set up for multipurpose.

97
00:04:44.200 --> 00:04:48.700
It might support client authentications,
smart card log on, and EFS,

98
00:04:48.700 --> 00:04:50.090
Encrypting File System.

99
00:04:50.090 --> 00:04:55.180
Or your organization might decide to
issue out single purpose certificates,

100
00:04:55.180 --> 00:04:58.000
where one certificate is good for
client authentication, but

101
00:04:58.000 --> 00:05:01.190
a separate certificate for
smart card logon.

102
00:05:01.190 --> 00:05:05.660
And a separate certificate for
EFS or something like that.

103
00:05:05.660 --> 00:05:06.360
>> Okay.

104
00:05:06.360 --> 00:05:07.840
>> And that could be due to many reasons.

105
00:05:07.840 --> 00:05:11.220
We talk about that more in the server
environment or the server classes.

106
00:05:11.220 --> 00:05:15.900
Where we talk about, how long they're good
for key lengths, and things like that.

107
00:05:15.900 --> 00:05:18.490
So, I might have several
virtual smart cards,

108
00:05:18.490 --> 00:05:21.190
each one with its own certificate for
a different purpose, right?

109
00:05:21.190 --> 00:05:22.370
>> Okay.
>> Or it could be multiple

110
00:05:22.370 --> 00:05:26.900
users on my system,
if it's a shared computer, all right?

111
00:05:26.900 --> 00:05:31.220
All right, so, and for the exam,
understand those limitations, right?

112
00:05:31.220 --> 00:05:35.540
TPM 1.2 or higher, Windows 8.1 or
later, minimum, or maximum,

113
00:05:35.540 --> 00:05:37.584
of ten virtual smart cards per computer.

114
00:05:37.584 --> 00:05:42.760
Aminimum 8 character PIN and the PIN is
what is associated with that smart card.

115
00:05:42.760 --> 00:05:46.190
Remember smart cards are basic,
they are multifactor authentication.

116
00:05:46.190 --> 00:05:47.890
You've got something you have.

117
00:05:47.890 --> 00:05:49.510
That's gonna be the smart card.

118
00:05:49.510 --> 00:05:52.440
And really it's the certificate
that's loaded up in that smart card

119
00:05:52.440 --> 00:05:53.710
is what I have.

120
00:05:53.710 --> 00:05:58.130
And then the PIN that's associated with
that smart card is the something I know.

121
00:05:58.130 --> 00:06:01.310
And this is what gives us that
multifactor authentication.

122
00:06:01.310 --> 00:06:05.960
And why smart cards are a much
more robust solution than using,

123
00:06:05.960 --> 00:06:09.040
say usernames and
passwords which are easy to share,

124
00:06:09.040 --> 00:06:13.800
easy to write down, have somebody
else intercept or see you type in.

125
00:06:13.800 --> 00:06:14.360
And many,

126
00:06:14.360 --> 00:06:18.600
many vulnerabilities associated with
using passwords as our authentication.

127
00:06:19.880 --> 00:06:21.880
All right, so now we've got an idea again,

128
00:06:21.880 --> 00:06:24.980
a virtual smart card is gonna
be a virtual smart card.

129
00:06:24.980 --> 00:06:26.790
It's not something I have,
it's stored in that TPM.

130
00:06:26.790 --> 00:06:31.890
We're also gonna have to request
a certificate that can get loaded up into

131
00:06:31.890 --> 00:06:32.930
that smart card.

132
00:06:32.930 --> 00:06:33.610
And if you think about it,

133
00:06:33.610 --> 00:06:36.260
this is the exact same thing that
happens in the physical world.

134
00:06:36.260 --> 00:06:37.700
Right, if I'm an organization and

135
00:06:37.700 --> 00:06:43.100
I'm gonna issues my users certificates,
I'm going to buy the physical smart card.

136
00:06:43.100 --> 00:06:46.600
I've got a machine that'll help me
load data onto those smart cards.

137
00:06:46.600 --> 00:06:50.420
I'm going to either request on
behalf of the user a certificate, or

138
00:06:50.420 --> 00:06:51.780
their gonna request it.

139
00:06:51.780 --> 00:06:54.520
I'm gonna load it up on my card,
and I'm gonna hand it to them.

140
00:06:54.520 --> 00:06:57.470
When we talk about virtual smart cards,
it's all the same,

141
00:06:57.470 --> 00:07:00.350
except there's no physical card, right?

142
00:07:00.350 --> 00:07:05.100
I'm gonna generate a card on my machine,
and it's gonna be stored in that TPM.

143
00:07:05.100 --> 00:07:07.590
And then I'm gonna
request a certificate and

144
00:07:07.590 --> 00:07:11.040
load it up onto that
generated virtual smart card.

145
00:07:11.040 --> 00:07:15.300
But other than that, it's gonna work
exactly the same as a physical smart card.

146
00:07:15.300 --> 00:07:20.010
In fact, it's pretty cool because once we
get it set up to Windows, it looks like

147
00:07:20.010 --> 00:07:24.910
you have a smart card reader plugged in,
and a smart card inserted all the time.

148
00:07:24.910 --> 00:07:27.330
So whenever you need it,
it's already there.

149
00:07:27.330 --> 00:07:28.000
>> That's pretty cool.

150
00:07:28.000 --> 00:07:32.300
>> It is, let's say your organization
uses smart cards to remote link access,

151
00:07:32.300 --> 00:07:34.110
some kind of web app that they have.

152
00:07:34.110 --> 00:07:36.880
Well, every time I have to go to
that web app, I've gotta remember,

153
00:07:36.880 --> 00:07:38.620
do I have my reader plugged in?

154
00:07:38.620 --> 00:07:39.800
Where's my darn smart card?

155
00:07:39.800 --> 00:07:40.810
Let me plug it in.

156
00:07:42.090 --> 00:07:44.010
With virtual smart cards,
I don't have to do any of that, right?

157
00:07:44.010 --> 00:07:47.900
It's already there and accessible by
the operating system as soon as I log in.

158
00:07:47.900 --> 00:07:51.806
>> So when you say already there, meaning
I don't have to purchase anything, or

159
00:07:51.806 --> 00:07:54.660
do I have any special tool or
download that I have to grab?

160
00:07:54.660 --> 00:07:55.320
>> Nothing, right?

161
00:07:55.320 --> 00:07:55.868
>> No, okay.

162
00:07:55.868 --> 00:07:57.780
>> Windows has it all built into it.

163
00:07:57.780 --> 00:07:58.960
So let's take a look at my screen here.

164
00:07:58.960 --> 00:08:00.820
I'll show you how to generate
a virtual smart card.

165
00:08:00.820 --> 00:08:04.710
We'll go and request a certificate, get
it loaded up and see how we can use it.

166
00:08:04.710 --> 00:08:05.350
>> Great.

167
00:08:05.350 --> 00:08:08.480
>> So I'm gonna fire up PowerShell, you
could use PowerShell or a command prompt.

168
00:08:08.480 --> 00:08:11.850
I do need to make sure I have
an administrative prompt, so

169
00:08:11.850 --> 00:08:13.000
let me do that one more time.

170
00:08:14.630 --> 00:08:19.100
Then I get my administrative credentials
running here and the command is gonna be

171
00:08:19.100 --> 00:08:24.210
tpmvscmgr, that's the utility
we're gonna be using.

172
00:08:24.210 --> 00:08:27.270
It always helps me to remember
if I know what it stands for,

173
00:08:27.270 --> 00:08:31.020
tpm virtual smart card manager.

174
00:08:31.020 --> 00:08:33.940
Sometimes I have to say it to myself as
I'm typing it to make sure I get that in

175
00:08:33.940 --> 00:08:39.540
the right order, tpmvsc,
virtual smart card, mgr, or manager.

176
00:08:39.540 --> 00:08:43.111
There's several switches
you can use with it.

177
00:08:43.111 --> 00:08:43.881
Oop, tpm, did I?

178
00:08:43.881 --> 00:08:44.897
>> You didn't do the .exe?

179
00:08:44.897 --> 00:08:46.276
>> [LAUGH] No, you know?

180
00:08:46.276 --> 00:08:46.866
>> What?
>> I was so

181
00:08:46.866 --> 00:08:48.742
worried about making sure I got VSC-
>> [LAUGH]

182
00:08:48.742 --> 00:08:49.898
>> In the right order,

183
00:08:49.898 --> 00:08:51.729
I put tmp instead of tpm.

184
00:08:51.729 --> 00:08:53.041
>> Yes.
>> So temporary, yeah.

185
00:08:53.041 --> 00:08:53.852
>> It's not temporary?

186
00:08:53.852 --> 00:08:55.396
[LAUGH]
>> No, it's not, so

Configure Windows Devices theories

Cherokee.

14
00:00:37.635 --> 00:00:40.146
And yeah, in this one we're gonna
take a look at something known

15
00:00:40.146 --> 00:00:41.132
as homegroups, right?

16
00:00:41.132 --> 00:00:43.109
They call out on our objectives,

17
00:00:43.109 --> 00:00:47.708
being able to differentiate between

18
00:00:47.708 --> 00:00:51.130
And they call that homegroups and
we need to understand what they are and

19
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:53.652
how we can use them, and
what their imitations are.

20
00:00:53.652 --> 00:00:55.419
So let's start by just defining.

21
00:00:55.419 --> 00:01:00.054
When we look at a homegroup, a homegroup
is designed to be an easy way to

22
00:01:00.054 --> 00:01:04.073
share resources amongst computers
on a local area network.

23
00:01:04.073 --> 00:01:08.781
Similar to what we might have done
earlier with say, workgroups.

24
00:01:08.781 --> 00:01:12.036
But they're a lot easier to set up,
a lot easier for

25
00:01:12.036 --> 00:01:16.525
a non-IT person or typical home users,
think your parents, right?

26
00:01:16.525 --> 00:01:21.883
People like that, to set up and again be
able to share resources amongst devices.

27
00:01:21.883 --> 00:01:24.743

28
00:01:24.743 --> 00:01:26.863

29

It's been around for a little while,

30
00:01:30.267 --> 00:01:34.655
But we would need our Windows 10 machines,

00:01:39.327 --> 00:01:42.614

35
00:01:45.291 --> 00:01:48.280
Otherwise, they won't be able
to join the homegroup and

36
00:01:48.280 --> 00:01:50.222

37
00:01:50.222 --> 00:01:53.567
Remember with Windows 10,
the first time you connect to a network,

38
00:01:53.567 --> 00:01:56.811
it's gonna ask you, is this a public
network or a private network.

39
00:01:56.811 --> 00:02:02.110
And we can only create and

40
00:02:02.110 --> 00:02:05.695

if somebody on the network has already

00:02:08.302 --> 00:02:11.562

00:02:16.054 --> 00:02:18.002
only one homegroup per network.

45
00:02:18.002 --> 00:02:20.703
And it'll end up generating a password.

46

47

49

It's really, again,
designed to be very simple and easy, so

50
00:02:32.449 --> 00:02:35.130
it's not real granular control.

51
00:02:35.130 --> 00:02:37.341
We're gonna be able to choose, hey,
do you wanna make your pictures available?

52
00:02:37.341 --> 00:02:41.551

53
00:02:41.551 --> 00:02:44.860

54
00:02:44.860 --> 00:02:47.851
You just say, yes or no, if you wanna
make those resources available.

55
00:02:47.851 --> 00:02:51.730
This isn't like setting up a share on

56
00:02:51.730 --> 00:02:53.099
that granular control.

57
00:02:53.099 --> 00:02:57.214
And I wanna give some people read
access and other people write access.

58
00:02:57.214 --> 00:03:00.503
This is again, a very simplistic for
those home networks.

59
00:03:00.503 --> 00:03:03.030
We don't need that type of control.

So you've got to go and

[COUGH] So bad,

bad performance when it comes to

Those are dynamic disks, and some of

00:21:06.330 --> 00:21:07.650
as well as some of the good things about.

00:21:08.650 --> 00:21:13.200
The last type I wanna show you is

00:21:13.200 --> 00:21:16.560
Differencing disks are a really

00:21:17.850 --> 00:21:19.100
They're called differencing.

376
00:21:19.100 --> 00:21:21.030
Did I spell differencing right?

00:21:21.030 --> 00:21:22.810
Make sure I spelled that right.

00:21:22.810 --> 00:21:26.770

00:21:26.770 --> 00:21:30.810

00:21:30.810 --> 00:21:36.221

00:21:36.221 --> 00:21:37.001

they also have some serious performance
issues that we're gonna have to deal with,

384
00:21:46.978 --> 00:21:48.130
as well.

385
00:21:48.130 --> 00:21:53.400
Right, so the way this works is,
I'm gonna take a parent VHD,

00:21:53.400 --> 00:21:56.440
let's say I've got my

00:21:56.440 --> 00:22:00.600
I've got some common files,

00:22:00.600 --> 00:22:01.750
I went ahead and installed everything,

00:22:01.750 --> 00:22:04.670
I did my Windows updates maybe and

00:22:04.670 --> 00:22:09.440
Now, I'm going to create a new VHD,

00:22:09.440 --> 00:22:14.020
And when I do this, it's going to ask me,

00:22:14.020 --> 00:22:16.770
And I'm going to point it to here.

393
00:22:16.770 --> 00:22:21.630
So I'll create a new VM using
this differencing disk, and

00:22:21.630 --> 00:22:24.450
it will write all of its changes to here.

395
00:22:24.450 --> 00:22:31.770
But it will still go back to the parent
VHD to get those base files, if you will.

396
00:22:31.770 --> 00:22:34.620
I use this technique often.

397
00:22:34.620 --> 00:22:35.870
I don't do it as much anymore,

00:22:35.870 --> 00:22:38.830

00:22:41.750 --> 00:22:44.780
differencing disks were,

00:22:44.780 --> 00:22:47.640
Because let's say I need to spin up a lab.

00:22:52.850 --> 00:22:55.457
Well, if I'm using fixed or dynamic,

00:22:55.457 --> 00:22:59.491
I'm going to install server
2016 three times, right?

00:22:59.491 --> 00:23:01.400
To create each one of
those virtual machines.

406
00:23:01.400 --> 00:23:04.700
I'm gonna do Windows updates

407
00:23:04.700 --> 00:23:06.780
each one of those needs to be updated,

408
00:23:06.780 --> 00:23:09.540
But now I have got three virtual machines.

409
00:23:09.540 --> 00:23:14.436
Or I could install server
2016 once here on a VHD and

00:23:14.436 --> 00:23:17.637
I could do all the Windows updates.

411
00:23:17.637 --> 00:23:22.269
Then I could set that drive aside and
I could make three new VMs,

412
00:23:22.269 --> 00:23:27.640
using differencing disks that all
point back to the parent VHD.

413
00:23:27.640 --> 00:23:32.350
They've already got Windows Server 2016
installed and all of the updates, so

00:23:32.350 --> 00:23:34.800
I can spin this up,
I could spin up another one.

415
00:23:36.191 --> 00:23:39.224
Right and just point it to,

416
00:23:40.982 --> 00:23:45.220
If I can get this over here, right,
point it back to that parent.

417
00:23:45.220 --> 00:23:49.510
If I want another one,
I just sped up another one, and

418
00:23:49.510 --> 00:23:52.020
point it back to the parent.

419
00:23:52.020 --> 00:23:54.330
I don't have to install anything, alright?

420
00:23:54.330 --> 00:23:58.618
So in this one maybe I installed ENS on
this one I installed EHTP, on this one I

421
00:23:58.618 --> 00:24:03.046
don't know I had to make my domain
controller alright or something like that.

422
00:24:03.046 --> 00:24:08.698
All based off of this same parent VHD,
so in order to install server 2016 Once,

423
00:24:08.698 --> 00:24:14.046
the only thing that's stored in here is
gonna be the fact that I installed DNS.

424
00:24:14.046 --> 00:24:17.608
That's different from this guy right,
differencing disks,

425
00:24:17.608 --> 00:24:19.297
they store the differences.

426
00:24:19.297 --> 00:24:23.854
Everything that's the same gets
stored in here, all right?

427
00:24:23.854 --> 00:24:26.547
Now, a couple things about these
differencing disks and I'll show you,

428
00:24:26.547 --> 00:24:29.588
we'll get into another episode and I'll
show you, we'll create some of these and

429
00:24:29.588 --> 00:24:31.720
it'll probably make a little more sense.

430
00:24:31.720 --> 00:24:33.240
You have to be really careful with these.

431
00:24:33.240 --> 00:24:37.426
First off, this parent vhd cannot change.

432
00:24:37.426 --> 00:24:41.650
Once you create a differencing disk
that points back to the parent,

433
00:24:41.650 --> 00:24:45.440
if the parent ever changes,
you break that link.

434
00:24:45.440 --> 00:24:48.400
It'll no longer recognize
it as the parent.

435
00:24:48.400 --> 00:24:49.840
And it won't work anymore.

436
00:24:49.840 --> 00:24:54.740
So this disk cannot change once I
point a differencing disk to it.

437
00:24:54.740 --> 00:25:00.010
Many times, we actually go into
the file system and mark the parent vhd

438
00:25:00.010 --> 00:25:04.390
as read-only, because I don't wanna
take a chance on this changing.

439
00:25:04.390 --> 00:25:08.190
Because, now, if this changes,
I don't lose one machine.

440
00:25:08.190 --> 00:25:12.220
But I would lose all three of my machines
that I had based off of that parent.

441
00:25:12.220 --> 00:25:13.280
So something to be aware of.

442
00:25:13.280 --> 00:25:17.090
The parent drive cannot change once
you create a differencing disk

443
00:25:17.090 --> 00:25:17.890
that points to it.

444
00:25:19.106 --> 00:25:24.970
Performance is not gonna be all that
good because DNS is installed here,

445
00:25:24.970 --> 00:25:30.650
DHCP is here, but the core Windows Server
2016 files are all back here.

446
00:25:30.650 --> 00:25:33.090
So if these two machines
are running at the same time,

447
00:25:33.090 --> 00:25:36.240
they're both gonna be reading from
their own differencing disk, but

448
00:25:36.240 --> 00:25:41.530
they're also both gonna hitting that
parent vhd for all the common files.

449
00:25:41.530 --> 00:25:46.440
If I fire up a third machine,
it's also reaching back to the parent vhd.

450
00:25:46.440 --> 00:25:51.502
So I've got a lot of disk contention for
reads going to that parent disk,

451
00:25:51.502 --> 00:25:55.470
I've got three different VMs all trying
to read from that one parent disk, and

452
00:25:55.470 --> 00:25:59.040
that can cause some serious
performance issues.

453
00:25:59.040 --> 00:26:02.180
So this is definitely something that you
won't see in a production environment,

454
00:26:02.180 --> 00:26:06.890
this is not even a consideration for
the most part.

455
00:26:06.890 --> 00:26:09.790
But in test labs where space is limited or

456
00:26:09.790 --> 00:26:13.320
time is a concern, right,
this is the way to go.

457
00:26:15.080 --> 00:26:20.096
I've talked on the other shows I have a
virtual hard drive that has a sys prepped

00:26:20.096 --> 00:26:25.574
2016 machine, 2012 machine,
Windows 10 machine, Windows 8 machine.

00:26:25.574 --> 00:26:28.662
If I ever need to I can just
spin up a differencing disk and

point it back to those guys and
spin up a machine really quick.

461
00:26:32.102 --> 00:26:34.711
I don't have to worry about installation-
>> That's a great idea.

462
00:26:34.711 --> 00:26:35.566
>> Don't have to worry about updates.

00:26:35.566 --> 00:26:36.341
It's ready to go.

464
00:26:36.341 --> 00:26:39.186
So if I just need to hey,

00:26:39.186 --> 00:26:42.800
I can spin up a new differencing
disk based off of that parent disk.

466
00:26:42.800 --> 00:26:43.810
Try it out.

467
00:26:43.810 --> 00:26:44.842
Blow it away.

468
00:26:44.842 --> 00:26:47.840
The parent disk didn't change so if I
ever need another one, it's still there.

469
00:26:47.840 --> 00:26:50.685
I can just create my differencing
all over again, all right?

470
00:26:50.685 --> 00:26:53.655
So really good for certain scenarios.

471
00:26:53.655 --> 00:26:55.504
And that's the key here, I think.

472
00:26:55.504 --> 00:27:00.480
And as you're preparing for this exam, is

00:27:00.480 --> 00:27:03.070

00:27:17.210 --> 00:27:21.460

00:27:23.760 --> 00:27:28.340
They have made a lot of improvements

481
00:27:28.340 --> 00:27:30.050

00:27:30.050 --> 00:27:33.490

00:28:05.540 --> 00:28:08.320
So if one of those drives

00:28:08.320 --> 00:28:10.780

00:28:10.780 --> 00:28:15.710

00:28:21.010 --> 00:28:24.630

00:28:24.630 --> 00:28:27.310
So that's definitely something that

00:28:27.310 --> 00:28:29.280

00:28:29.280 --> 00:28:32.460
It also has to do with that underlying
architecture that you're using.

499
00:28:32.460 --> 00:28:35.570
So I can't tell you you'll
never use them in production.

500
00:28:35.570 --> 00:28:38.580
Microsoft will tell you that
they've made great improvements and

00:28:38.580 --> 00:28:40.820

use them in production.

502
00:28:40.820 --> 00:28:43.800
But it's something that I would
definitely want to test out.

503
00:28:43.800 --> 00:28:47.160
Differencing disks, yeah,
probably not either.

504
00:28:47.160 --> 00:28:50.520
But again, Microsoft has made
great strides to make them better.

505
00:28:50.520 --> 00:28:53.270
It's definitely something that
you're gonna have to test out.

I wanna be able to configure all of those
salespeoples' laptops by using a policy.

562
00:29:06.314 --> 00:29:10.370
So this is how you're gonna do it many
times in a corporate environment.

563
00:29:10.370 --> 00:29:13.219
Now on the exam,
their favorite thing to say is,

564
00:29:13.219 --> 00:29:17.810
how would you accomplish this with
the least administrative effort?

565
00:29:17.810 --> 00:29:19.450
And that means you're
gonna be using policy,

566
00:29:19.450 --> 00:29:22.920
you're not gonna be touching
every single machine, right?

567
00:29:22.920 --> 00:29:24.280
All right, last thing I wanna show you.

568
00:29:24.280 --> 00:29:28.990
I promise there is no way to
create power plans through here.

569
00:29:28.990 --> 00:29:31.570
I showed you, you can specify a custom.

570
00:29:31.570 --> 00:29:36.200
But that just means telling it what
the GUID is of an existing power plan,

571
00:29:36.200 --> 00:29:37.240
that's no fun.

572
00:29:37.240 --> 00:29:40.950
We can create power plans through
here using group policy preferences.

573
00:29:40.950 --> 00:29:42.124
And I'll just show you where it is.

574
00:29:42.124 --> 00:29:46.270
I'll go down to Preferences and
let me scroll up so

575
00:29:46.270 --> 00:29:48.290
I can zoom in a little bit here.

576
00:29:48.290 --> 00:29:54.450
And then we're gonna go in to
Control Panel > Power Options.

577
00:29:54.450 --> 00:29:57.615
Now we'll talk a lot
more about Preferences,

578
00:29:57.615 --> 00:30:03.308
how are different from group policies when
we get into our server classes, right?

579
00:30:03.308 --> 00:30:09.547
But just so you can see, I can
right-click here, New > Power Options.

580
00:30:09.547 --> 00:30:16.035
And I will wanna do Windows 7, cuz that's
gonna be for my Windows 10 machines.

581
00:30:16.035 --> 00:30:19.092
And I'll zoom back out, and
this should look familiar, right?

582
00:30:19.092 --> 00:30:21.630
This is that same screen we
were looking at from the client

583
00:30:21.630 --> 00:30:24.348
side when I wanted to
do a custom power plan.

584
00:30:24.348 --> 00:30:27.940
And I wanted to look at all those advanced
settings, I have them all right here.

585
00:30:27.940 --> 00:30:31.590
So I could go through, configure
all of this power plan options and

586
00:30:31.590 --> 00:30:34.880
then set it to replace their
existing power plan, so

587
00:30:34.880 --> 00:30:39.440
that I can use to create a custom plan and
assign it to those machines.

588
00:30:39.440 --> 00:30:42.180
So that takes care of really,
Cherokee, of our power options.

589
00:30:42.180 --> 00:30:45.750
We've taken a look at how I can
configure those from the laptop,

590
00:30:45.750 --> 00:30:49.600
from the device as an individual laptop.

591
00:30:49.600 --> 00:30:52.510
Also wanted to show you a little bit
about the group policy side of things

592
00:30:52.510 --> 00:30:54.590
where we can configure this
on an enterprise level.

593
00:30:54.590 --> 00:30:56.620
>> Great information as always, Mike.

594
00:30:56.620 --> 00:31:01.600
I'm feeling a little guilty here because I
know my power settings are not optimized.

595
00:31:01.600 --> 00:31:04.370
So now they should be from everything
that you've shown us today, but

596
00:31:04.370 --> 00:31:05.400
thank you so much.

597
00:31:05.400 --> 00:31:08.600
Thank you guys for joining us, but
we are out of time, so let's sign out.

598
00:31:08.600 --> 00:31:10.040
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

599
00:31:10.040 --> 00:31:10.789
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

00:31:10.789 --> 00:31:14.464
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

00:00:23.740 --> 00:00:27.220
And, of course,

Mike Roderick, how's it going, Mike?

>> I'm doing good, Cherokee,
thanks for having me back,

>> I know,

>> [LAUGH]
>> So the next time you see us,

And if we were at the beach and

19

Well, we could use this great

00:00:52.430 --> 00:00:54.546
I don't know if that was
a great segue into it, but hey,

00:00:54.546 --> 00:00:55.592
we're going to go with it.

00:00:55.592 --> 00:00:57.870
>> It is an option, though,
we do have that option.

23
00:00:57.870 --> 00:00:59.260
>> It is an option, right?

24
00:00:59.260 --> 00:01:02.590
So that's what we're here to talk about
today is something known as Windows To Go.

25
00:01:02.590 --> 00:01:05.334
It's been around for
a couple of versions of Windows,

26
00:01:05.334 --> 00:01:08.806
I believe starting with 8 maybe or
8.1, don't quote me on that.

27
00:01:08.806 --> 00:01:12.889
But it's definitely here on Windows 10,
and that's what we're studying for,

28
00:01:12.889 --> 00:01:16.520
all right, is that 70-697 exam for
configuring Windows devices.

29
00:01:16.520 --> 00:01:20.714
So first let's talk about what
the heck Windows To Go is.

30
00:01:20.714 --> 00:01:21.858
And what it is,

31
00:01:21.858 --> 00:01:27.110
is a way to install Windows
operating system on removable media.

32
00:01:27.110 --> 00:01:30.198
And then be able to take
that with me wherever I go,

33
00:01:30.198 --> 00:01:33.446
hence the name Windows To Go,
now think about that.

34
00:01:33.446 --> 00:01:36.802
So if I can install Windows
10 on a thumb drive, or

35
00:01:36.802 --> 00:01:41.820
what I'm going to do in our show here
is a little portable hard drive.

36
00:01:41.820 --> 00:01:44.641
I can install Windows 10 on
that portable hard drive,

37
00:01:44.641 --> 00:01:47.773
full blown copy of the operating system,
everything I need.

38
00:01:47.773 --> 00:01:51.870
I can install applications,
Internet access, all of that.

39
00:01:51.870 --> 00:01:55.988
When I go traveling,
instead of packing up my laptop and

40
00:01:55.988 --> 00:01:59.679
my charger, my power block and
all of that stuff.

41
00:01:59.679 --> 00:02:01.951
My mouse, and
everything I need for that laptop,

42
00:02:01.951 --> 00:02:06.510
if I know there's hardware available where
I'm going, I can simply take this with me.

43
00:02:06.510 --> 00:02:09.784
Plug it into any machine that is
capable of running Windows 10.

44
00:02:09.784 --> 00:02:12.154
And we know the hardware requirements for

45
00:02:12.154 --> 00:02:15.140
Windows 10 are really
not very steep at all.

46
00:02:15.140 --> 00:02:18.136
And I can have my machine,
all of my documents, all of my stuff,

47
00:02:18.136 --> 00:02:19.145
right there with me.

48
00:02:19.145 --> 00:02:23.216
And I'm ready to go,
I unplug it, every hotel has a-

49
00:02:23.216 --> 00:02:24.322
>> Kiosk or something.

50
00:02:24.322 --> 00:02:26.722
>> Kiosk, yeah, or a business center-
>> A shared whatever.

51
00:02:26.722 --> 00:02:28.550
>> Where I can go down there, absolutely.

52
00:02:28.550 --> 00:02:33.402
>> I know, at first,
when I was thinking about different ways

53
00:02:33.402 --> 00:02:38.268
to use this feature,
I had to jump into some super spy mode.

54
00:02:38.268 --> 00:02:39.952
Because I'm like, yeah,
you could just take this anywhere.

55
00:02:39.952 --> 00:02:43.619
Plug it into someone's computer and boot
off of it, and have your own system, but

56
00:02:43.619 --> 00:02:44.961
really, you could, [LAUGH].

57
00:02:44.961 --> 00:02:49.258
>> Yeah, absolutely, if your job is to
go to some organization and do audits or

58
00:02:49.258 --> 00:02:51.940
testing of some kind, things like that.

59
00:02:51.940 --> 00:02:55.185
I could bring my install of Windows,
all of my tools are on there,

60
00:02:55.185 --> 00:02:58.020
I know they've got a PC that I can use,
I can boot up to it.

61
00:02:58.020 --> 00:03:02.117
And we'll talk about some security
features that are built into Windows To Go

62
00:03:02.117 --> 00:03:03.260
to help keep us safe.

63
00:03:03.260 --> 00:03:07.690
Also keep the systems that we're plugging
into safe, and things like that as we go.

64
00:03:07.690 --> 00:03:12.300
So that's the general concept is,
installing Windows on removable media.

65
00:03:12.300 --> 00:03:16.167
And being able to take it on the go,
hence the name Windows To Go.

66
00:03:16.167 --> 00:03:19.533
So let's start by talking about
some of the capabilities,

67
00:03:19.533 --> 00:03:22.561
some of the capabilities,
some of the features, and

68
00:03:22.561 --> 00:03:25.257
some of the-
>> Limitations?

69
00:03:25.257 --> 00:03:29.267
>> Limitations, yeah, that would be
a good way to put it, limitations of, and

70
00:03:29.267 --> 00:03:32.371
I think we'll just jump out
to Microsoft's website here.

71
00:03:32.371 --> 00:03:35.209
Because they've got a nice
little summary here for us, and

72
00:03:35.209 --> 00:03:38.355
I'll put the link in the show notes,
but let's talk about this.

73
00:03:38.355 --> 00:03:40.712
This is just out to TechNet,
or docs.microsoft.com.

74
00:03:40.712 --> 00:03:44.248
And what I want to show you is some of
the differences between Windows To Go and

75
00:03:44.248 --> 00:03:45.700
a typical install of Windows.

76
00:03:45.700 --> 00:03:47.869
Because there are some
things that might or

77
00:03:47.869 --> 00:03:51.380
might not make Windows To Go
the perfect solution for you.

78
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:54.218
First of all, internal disks are offline.

79
00:03:54.218 --> 00:03:58.630
So when I plug in this
Windows To Go drive into a machine.

80
00:03:58.630 --> 00:04:01.568
And I boot up to that
Windows To Go installation,

81
00:04:01.568 --> 00:04:04.156
I will not have access
to the local drives.

82
00:04:04.156 --> 00:04:08.610
So that means whomever's computer I'm
using, if I'm at some other organization.

83
00:04:08.610 --> 00:04:12.918
They don't have to worry about me getting
into things that are on that machine.

84
00:04:12.918 --> 00:04:14.648
I could use Cherokee's laptop and

85
00:04:14.648 --> 00:04:17.760
I couldn't access Cherokee's
information on that laptop.

86
00:04:17.760 --> 00:04:20.745
Because the internal drives
won't be brought online,

87
00:04:20.745 --> 00:04:24.375
there's no map that drives to them
when you boot up to Windows To Go.

88
00:04:24.375 --> 00:04:29.100
And the same thing, if the Windows To Go
drive is inserted into a running system.

89
00:04:29.100 --> 00:04:34.295
The Windows To Go drive will not be
listed in that local install of Windows.

90
00:04:34.295 --> 00:04:39.263
So they wouldn't be able to browse through
and look at your Windows To Go drive, so

91
00:04:39.263 --> 00:04:40.200
that's good.

92
00:04:40.200 --> 00:04:42.304
TPM is not going to be used, all right?

93
00:04:42.304 --> 00:04:44.701
And that's because this is mobile,
remember,

94
00:04:44.701 --> 00:04:46.600
a TPM, the trusted platform module.

95
00:04:46.600 --> 00:04:51.088
This is where we can store the key
information for things like BitLocker.

96
00:04:51.088 --> 00:04:55.188
But if I'm taking this drive from
one machine to another to another,

97
00:04:55.188 --> 00:04:57.670
I'm not taking the TPM chip with me.

98
00:04:57.670 --> 00:04:59.950
So if I stored any keying
information in there,

99
00:04:59.950 --> 00:05:02.975
it wouldn't do me any good if I
was at some other organization.

100
00:05:02.975 --> 00:05:05.310
And I tried to plug in my Windows To Go.

101
00:05:05.310 --> 00:05:08.329
Obviously, the TPM chip
wouldn't be there and

102
00:05:08.329 --> 00:05:13.321
I wouldn't have that key information,
so we can't use BitLocker using TPM.

103
00:05:13.321 --> 00:05:14.505
>> In a physical sense.

104
00:05:14.505 --> 00:05:17.259
>> Yes, we can use BitLocker
with a password, right?

105
00:05:17.259 --> 00:05:20.850
So we can still use BitLocker
to encrypt the drive,

106
00:05:20.850 --> 00:05:24.952
we just can't use the,
TPM is a place to store those keys.

107
00:05:24.952 --> 00:05:28.300
>> And I saw someone,
they had set up a flash drive with this.

108
00:05:28.300 --> 00:05:30.354
>> Mm-hm.
>> And the actual manufacturer, and

109
00:05:30.354 --> 00:05:34.950
I'm sure you'll tell us about this, but
they had epoxy all on top of the chipsets.

110
00:05:34.950 --> 00:05:36.950
So that the actual chips
could not be modified,

111
00:05:36.950 --> 00:05:38.888
I just thought that that was really cool.

112
00:05:38.888 --> 00:05:39.616
>> Really?

113
00:05:39.616 --> 00:05:41.730
Interesting, nice, as long as it doesn't
overheat, I guess, you're good to go.

114
00:05:41.730 --> 00:05:45.282
>> I was thinking about that too, but
I don't know, it was over $700 so

115
00:05:45.282 --> 00:05:47.355
I didn't buy it to test it, Mike.

116
00:05:47.355 --> 00:05:47.915
>> Okay.

117
00:05:47.915 --> 00:05:48.628
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well,

118
00:05:48.628 --> 00:05:52.260
they must have done their testing if
they're charging $700 for it, hopefully.

119
00:05:52.260 --> 00:05:56.464
All right, so TPM's not going to be used,
Hibernate is disabled by default, again,

120
00:05:56.464 --> 00:05:57.973
same kind of concept, right?

121
00:05:57.973 --> 00:06:02.073
When we go into hibernation, we write
everything that's in memory to that

122
00:06:02.073 --> 00:06:05.830
hiberfil.sys, and
that's stored in the local hard drive.

123
00:06:05.830 --> 00:06:08.991
And if I go and take that to another
machine and try to wake it up,

124
00:06:08.991 --> 00:06:11.088
different hardware, things like that.

125
00:06:11.088 --> 00:06:16.080
It's going to cause major problems,
so hibernate is going to be disabled,

126
00:06:16.080 --> 00:06:17.670
it can be re-enabled.

127
00:06:17.670 --> 00:06:22.308
Like I said, it can cause some issues
though, the hyper file will be written to

128
00:06:22.308 --> 00:06:25.490
the local drive, I mean,
to the Windows To Go drive.

129
00:06:25.490 --> 00:06:29.396
So it's not like it stays like the TPM,
but again, different machines,

130
00:06:29.396 --> 00:06:33.940
different configurations, it can
definitely cause some problems there.

131
00:06:33.940 --> 00:06:37.246
Windows Recovery Environment is
not going to be available either,

132
00:06:37.246 --> 00:06:39.743
do you have a problem with
your Windows To Go drive?

133
00:06:39.743 --> 00:06:43.727
You should just reinstall Windows on it,
that's Microsoft's recommendation.

134
00:06:43.727 --> 00:06:49.479
You're not trying to save it and
repair it, you're just going to reinstall.

135
00:06:49.479 --> 00:06:52.593
>> So
I could see this particular use case,

136
00:06:52.593 --> 00:06:56.620
something like if I have
an Internet connection.

137
00:06:56.620 --> 00:06:59.783
If I have a lot of files that I need to
save and retain, it might be better just

138
00:06:59.783 --> 00:07:02.559
to go ahead and store them up
to the Cloud, what do you think?

139
00:07:02.559 --> 00:07:03.398
>> Absoutely, yeah.

140
00:07:03.398 --> 00:07:07.399
If you're worried about that, if you are
feeling like, if something goes wrong with

141
00:07:07.399 --> 00:07:10.990
this, then I have to reinstall or
lose a lot of information.

142
00:07:10.990 --> 00:07:13.750
Definitely use your One Drive,
for example.

143
00:07:13.750 --> 00:07:17.476
Store that information there, and
now you have no problem blowing away and

144
00:07:17.476 --> 00:07:20.230
reinstalling Windows, absolutely.

145
00:07:20.230 --> 00:07:23.772
Refreshing or resetting the Windows To Go
workspace is not supported.

146
00:07:23.772 --> 00:07:27.636
Again, just go ahead and
reimage the device, it's much easier,

147
00:07:27.636 --> 00:07:31.170
upgrading a Windows To Go
workspace is not supported.

148
00:07:31.170 --> 00:07:34.138
So if you built this on Windows 8 or
Windows 8.1,

149
00:07:34.138 --> 00:07:37.382
you can't upgrade to
Windows To Go before Windows 10.

150
00:07:37.382 --> 00:07:39.953
You would just need to rebuild the drives,
so

151
00:07:39.953 --> 00:07:43.900
there are some differences with
the versions are there, all right?

152
00:07:43.900 --> 00:07:46.894
Again, a lot of good reading here
if you want to go through and

153
00:07:46.894 --> 00:07:48.970
read this out on docs.microsoft.com.

154
00:07:48.970 --> 00:07:53.560
But I do want to show you one
other important section down here

155
00:07:53.560 --> 00:07:55.273
about the USB drives.

156
00:07:55.273 --> 00:08:00.222
Because we are talking about running an
operating system from an external drive.

157
00:08:00.222 --> 00:08:05.470
So we need to make sure that those drives
have the appropriate level of performance.

158
00:08:05.470 --> 00:08:07.620
Really, it's all about random reads and

159
00:08:07.620 --> 00:08:11.254
writes that occur when you're
running an operating system, right?

160
00:08:11.254 --> 00:08:14.488
There's all kinds of things going
on in the background, system calls,

161
00:08:14.488 --> 00:08:17.881
hardware talking to the operating system
and calling back to the hardware,

162
00:08:17.881 --> 00:08:20.425
things like that, above and
beyond what you're doing,

163
00:08:20.425 --> 00:08:22.410
opening up a Word document or
what have you.

164
00:08:22.410 --> 00:08:25.044
There's a lot of reads and
writes going on.

165
00:08:25.044 --> 00:08:27.396
And if you don't have
the proper throughput,

166
00:08:27.396 --> 00:08:29.577
it's gonna cause a performance problem.

167
00:08:29.577 --> 00:08:33.241
And Microsoft doesn't want you
trying out Windows to Go and going,

168
00:08:33.241 --> 00:08:34.600
[SOUND] this is horrible.

169
00:08:34.600 --> 00:08:35.266
>> Lame [LAUGH].

170
00:08:35.266 --> 00:08:38.928
>> Yeah, so we wanna make sure we're
using hardware that is supported and

171
00:08:38.928 --> 00:08:42.910
recommended for Microsoft, so we that
we can get that level of performance.

172
00:08:42.910 --> 00:08:47.560
You can see here Windows To Go certified
drives high random read/writes,

173
00:08:47.560 --> 00:08:50.900
support thousands of random
I/O operations per second.

174
00:08:50.900 --> 00:08:54.360
That is normally occurring
when you're running Windows.

175
00:08:54.360 --> 00:08:56.480
And they've also been tuned
to ensure they boot and

176
00:08:56.480 --> 00:08:59.660
run on hardware with Windows 7 and later.

177
00:08:59.660 --> 00:09:01.520
And they're supposedly built to last.

178
00:09:01.520 --> 00:09:05.329
You were talking about the $700
one with epoxy in there.

179
00:09:05.329 --> 00:09:07.058
>> Yeah.
>> These devices are supposed to

180
00:09:07.058 --> 00:09:08.625
be a little better quality.

181
00:09:08.625 --> 00:09:12.789
>> With steel enclosures,

but for now, let's sign out.

594
00:34:22.132 --> 00:34:24.970
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

Setting it in, not so much but

25

26
00:00:54.902 --> 00:00:59.561
let's talk about we're talking about
the 697, Configuring Windows Devices.

27
00:00:59.561 --> 00:01:04.133
So we're gonna talk about how do we
configure our device to use DNS.

28
00:01:04.133 --> 00:01:06.126
And let's just take a step back and

29
00:01:06.126 --> 00:01:11.190
make sure we're all on the same page when
we talk about DNS or Domain Name System.

30
00:01:11.190 --> 00:01:16.840
This is a service that our machines use
to resolve names into IP addresses.

31
00:01:16.840 --> 00:01:19.291
And to be more specific and correct,

32
00:01:19.291 --> 00:01:23.414
we would say fully qualified
domain names into IP addresses.

33
00:01:23.414 --> 00:01:26.753
Because remember, PCs, computers,
they don't connect to names.

34
00:01:26.753 --> 00:01:28.244
They don't understand names.

35
00:01:28.244 --> 00:01:32.371
All they know are 1s and 0s,
and we use IP addresses.

36
00:01:32.371 --> 00:01:36.768
When we talk about creating a socket, for
example, between me and that Web server.

37
00:01:36.768 --> 00:01:42.530
Well, that socket is made up of protocol,
IP, and port number, right?

38
00:01:42.530 --> 00:01:43.390
There's no name in there.

39
00:01:43.390 --> 00:01:46.361
But as humans, we like names, right?
>> I don't know Mike.

40
00:01:46.361 --> 00:01:50.794
I mean, I remember every single IP address
for every single website that I go to.

41
00:01:50.794 --> 00:01:51.500
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,

42
00:01:51.500 --> 00:01:53.807
you're one of those savants?
>> Sure.

43
00:01:53.807 --> 00:01:55.110
>> Yeah, exactly.

44
00:01:55.110 --> 00:01:57.427
I mean, and we all know,
we go through this.

45
00:01:57.427 --> 00:02:01.270
I don't even know my dad's phone number
anymore because I can look him up in

46
00:02:01.270 --> 00:02:03.598
a list and touch Dad and
it calls him, right?

47
00:02:03.598 --> 00:02:05.817
And it's the same thing here,
so yes, we like to use names.

48
00:02:05.817 --> 00:02:09.944
Cuz I can remember things like amazon.com,
facebook.com, google.com,

49
00:02:09.944 --> 00:02:11.328
whatever the case may be.

50
00:02:11.328 --> 00:02:13.576
Those are easy to remember as a human.

51
00:02:13.576 --> 00:02:18.162
But if you told me that
Amazon was 17.35.142.10,

52
00:02:18.162 --> 00:02:21.549
if had to remember that,
that would be a pain.

53
00:02:21.549 --> 00:02:23.995
And then what if Amazon change that?

54
00:02:23.995 --> 00:02:26.356
Now they've got to let everyone know
that their IP address has changed.

55
00:02:26.356 --> 00:02:29.450
So DNS solves a lot of those problems.

56
00:02:29.450 --> 00:02:30.856
We can use friendly names.

57
00:02:30.856 --> 00:02:32.893
They get translated, or resolved,

58
00:02:32.893 --> 00:02:37.437
in the background into an IP address that
my computer can use to actually connect.

59
00:02:37.437 --> 00:02:39.037
And if you want more
information about DNS.

60
00:02:39.037 --> 00:02:43.185
Make sure you go check out our server
classes where we do talk about how DNS

61
00:02:43.185 --> 00:02:47.137
works in the distributed hierarchical
system and things like that.

62
00:02:47.137 --> 00:02:50.672
Here, we really wanna focus on how
do I make sure that my client is

63
00:02:50.672 --> 00:02:51.987
configured properly?

64
00:02:51.987 --> 00:02:54.811
Cuz without DNS, Cherokee,
we're not doing a whole lot, are we?

65
00:02:54.811 --> 00:02:55.421
>> No, I mean,

66
00:02:55.421 --> 00:02:58.755
unless we know all those particular
IP addresses and then you're set!

67
00:02:58.755 --> 00:03:00.638
And you don't even need
to watch this show.

68
00:03:00.638 --> 00:03:01.988
>> Yeah so if you've got all them

69
00:03:01.988 --> 00:03:03.507
memorized, you're good to go.

70
00:03:03.507 --> 00:03:06.635
But everything we do it relies on DNS.

71
00:03:06.635 --> 00:03:11.046
From the moment you walk up to your
computer and you go to log in to work.

72
00:03:11.046 --> 00:03:15.350
Well, your computer has to find the domain
controller so you can be authenticated,

73
00:03:15.350 --> 00:03:16.876
and it does that through DNS.

74
00:03:16.876 --> 00:03:21.292
It uses SRV records to find the IP address
of the machine that's offering the logon

75
00:03:21.292 --> 00:03:24.307
or the authentication service,
and then it connects.

76
00:03:24.307 --> 00:03:28.047
So without DNS,
you can't even get past the logon screen.

77
00:03:28.047 --> 00:03:31.939
And then everything you do,
all the file shares you connect to,

78
00:03:31.939 --> 00:03:35.123
all the other machines you
might have to connect to.

79
00:03:35.123 --> 00:03:40.586
Your mapped drives, your cloud
service providers, your webpages.

80
00:03:40.586 --> 00:03:42.990
All of that relies on DNS.

81
00:03:42.990 --> 00:03:46.355
So just about everything we
do relies on this service.

82
00:03:46.355 --> 00:03:50.477
So making sure the client is configured
properly to use the right DNS servers,

83
00:03:50.477 --> 00:03:53.389
the ones that we want, is very important.
>> For sure and

84
00:03:53.389 --> 00:03:57.401
we're not just talking about
enterprise use, we're still using DNS.

85
00:03:57.401 --> 00:03:59.884
Even if we don't have a DNS
server on our network,

86
00:03:59.884 --> 00:04:01.727
we're gonna be using it elsewhere.

87
00:04:01.727 --> 00:04:05.060
Maybe from our Internet service
provider or something like that, but

88
00:04:05.060 --> 00:04:06.598
it still exists.
>> Exactly and

89
00:04:06.598 --> 00:04:08.514
that's a great starting point.

90
00:04:08.514 --> 00:04:11.861
We need, no matter what we're doing,
whether we are part of a work network or

91
00:04:11.861 --> 00:04:12.538
home network.

92
00:04:12.538 --> 00:04:16.721
Sitting at the Starbucks or
some other coffee shop, we need DNS.

93
00:04:16.721 --> 00:04:18.534
And the way our machine connects to DNS,

94
00:04:18.534 --> 00:04:20.676
that's really what we're
here to talk about.

95
00:04:20.676 --> 00:04:25.333
How does my machine know how
to find that DNS server?

96
00:04:25.333 --> 00:04:29.508
And take that name that I've typed
into my browser and convert into and

97
00:04:29.508 --> 00:04:31.438
IP address that it can connect?

98
00:04:31.438 --> 00:04:34.280
And that's through our TCP/IP settings.

99
00:04:34.280 --> 00:04:38.013
When we look at our TCP/IP settings,
we have several things we can configure.

100
00:04:38.013 --> 00:04:42.850
We have our IP address, our subnet mask,
our default gateway, and our DNS server.

101
00:04:42.850 --> 00:04:45.269
These are the four big ones,
there's more, but

102
00:04:45.269 --> 00:04:48.465
those are the main configurations
we do within our IP settings.

103
00:04:48.465 --> 00:04:51.726
So it's in our IP settings
that we configure DNS.

104
00:04:51.726 --> 00:04:55.028
And let's jump over here at my screen and
take a look.

105
00:04:55.028 --> 00:04:57.022
So I am on a Windows 10 box.

106
00:04:57.022 --> 00:04:59.319
[COUGH] Excuse me.

107
00:04:59.319 --> 00:05:01.788
And I'm gonna open up my network and
Internet.

108
00:05:01.788 --> 00:05:06.109
And I'm gonna head over to my Ethernet and
find my adapter.

109
00:05:06.109 --> 00:05:07.125
And yes, or course,

110
00:05:07.125 --> 00:05:10.357
there are many different you can
go to get to places in Windows 10.

111
00:05:10.357 --> 00:05:15.150
So whatever your favorite way is to
get to your network connections.

112
00:05:15.150 --> 00:05:18.630
And I'm gonna pull up the properties for
this network adapter.

113
00:05:18.630 --> 00:05:22.871
And on the Properties tab,
I see this IP version 4.

114
00:05:22.871 --> 00:05:27.146
And that's really what we're gonna focus
in on here in this particular show,

115
00:05:27.146 --> 00:05:28.196
is gonna be IPv4.

116
00:05:28.196 --> 00:05:30.184
When I double-click on that,

117
00:05:30.184 --> 00:05:33.781
I can see that it's set to
use the following IP address.

118
00:05:33.781 --> 00:05:37.940
And then there's a bunch of numbers
listed here for IP address, subnet mask,

119
00:05:37.940 --> 00:05:40.840
default gateway, and preferred DNS server.

120
00:05:40.840 --> 00:05:44.717
So let's first talk about
these two options here,

121
00:05:44.717 --> 00:05:49.868
because this includes how I'm
obtaining this DNS server address.

122
00:05:49.868 --> 00:05:52.083
Right now it's what we
call statically mapped.

123
00:05:52.083 --> 00:05:56.056
And that means that somebody has
gone in and actually typed in.

124
00:05:56.056 --> 00:05:58.053
In fact,
it was me earlier before the show.

125
00:05:58.053 --> 00:05:58.588
>> [LAUGH]

126
00:05:58.588 --> 00:05:59.449
>> I went in and

127
00:05:59.449 --> 00:06:02.213
typed in the number 8.8.8.8.

128
00:06:02.213 --> 00:06:06.705
That happens to be the IP address of a
publicly available DNS server out there on

129
00:06:06.705 --> 00:06:07.598
the Internet.

130
00:06:07.598 --> 00:06:11.843
I think that one's maintained
by Google if I'm not mistaken.

131
00:06:11.843 --> 00:06:15.014
So I've told it,
I come in here and I statically,

132
00:06:15.014 --> 00:06:19.102
manually assign the IP address
that I want this computer to use.

133
00:06:19.102 --> 00:06:22.510
So what that means is when it needs
to resolve a name into an IP address.

134
00:06:22.510 --> 00:06:26.935
Whether that's me logging on,
whether that's me visiting a webpage, or

135
00:06:26.935 --> 00:06:27.862
what have you.

136
00:06:27.862 --> 00:06:31.127
This is the IP address that
my system is going to use.

137
00:06:31.127 --> 00:06:35.300
It's gonna talk to that DNS server and say
hey, I need your help resolving his name

138
00:06:35.300 --> 00:06:37.801
into an IP address.
>> Right, so you don't own that,

139
00:06:37.801 --> 00:06:39.588
it's not your particular DNS server.

140
00:06:39.588 --> 00:06:42.630
Like you said, it's Google's,
and that one is easy to remember.

141
00:06:42.630 --> 00:06:45.810
But that's probably about one of
the few that I can actually remember.

142
00:06:45.810 --> 00:06:48.854
But anyways, so
you're still using DNS, right?

143
00:06:48.854 --> 00:06:52.636
So even though you don't have a DNS server
on your network, not everyone has to, but

144
00:06:52.636 --> 00:06:55.416
it is an option.
>> Exactly, and it should be, let's see.

145
00:06:55.416 --> 00:06:58.446
I haven't opened up the browser
on this machine since I set up.

146
00:06:58.446 --> 00:07:03.960
So I'm sure I have some crazy pages that
Microsoft is gonna want me to go to.

147
00:07:03.960 --> 00:07:07.559
So I just put in google.com,
we'll close some of this other stuff.

148
00:07:07.559 --> 00:07:11.193
There you can see I was
able to get to google.com.

149
00:07:11.193 --> 00:07:11.861
What's another one?

150
00:07:11.861 --> 00:07:14.238
Maybe we wanna go to amazon.com.

151
00:07:14.238 --> 00:07:16.252
So I'm typing in these names and

152
00:07:16.252 --> 00:07:20.590
my system in the background is
reaching out to that 8.8.8.8.

153
00:07:20.590 --> 00:07:23.426
And saying hey,
my user just typed in amazon.com.

154
00:07:23.426 --> 00:07:24.158
>> Where do I go?

155
00:07:24.158 --> 00:07:25.425
>> Yeah, what the heck is

156
00:07:25.425 --> 00:07:27.430
the IP address for that Web server?

157
00:07:27.430 --> 00:07:30.919
It does all that in the background without
us knowing it, and now there we go,

158
00:07:30.919 --> 00:07:32.999
I'm at amazon.com.
>> Ready to shop.

159
00:07:32.999 --> 00:07:35.237
>> Ready to spend my hard earned money,

160
00:07:35.237 --> 00:07:36.050
right?

161
00:07:36.050 --> 00:07:40.595
So one way we can set the DNS server
address on a client machine is statically.

162
00:07:40.595 --> 00:07:46.469
By opening up the TCP/IP properties and
filling it in, preferred DNS server.

163
00:07:46.469 --> 00:07:49.822
Now I'm gonna probably jump out of
order just a little bit here, Cherokee.

164
00:07:49.822 --> 00:07:54.657
And why we're on this screen, I wanna go
ahead and talk about the preferred and

165
00:07:54.657 --> 00:07:57.305
alternate, why we're here, all right?

166
00:07:57.305 --> 00:07:59.471
Because DNS is very important.

167
00:07:59.471 --> 00:08:04.048
We've decided and we've talked about
the fact that everything we do really

168
00:08:04.048 --> 00:08:08.567
relies On DNS, it's very rare that we
do anything by IP address directly.

169
00:08:08.567 --> 00:08:10.190
So DNS is important.

170
00:08:10.190 --> 00:08:14.520
Well what do you think is gonna
happen if 8.8.8.8 is unavailable,

171
00:08:14.520 --> 00:08:15.490
what happens to my system?

172
00:08:15.490 --> 00:08:17.317
Do I connect to those webpages still?
>> Well,

173
00:08:17.317 --> 00:08:20.862
you do have another line there available
but nothing's been configured, so

174
00:08:20.862 --> 00:08:22.998
the computer only does
what it we tell it to do.

175
00:08:22.998 --> 00:08:27.517
It's going to check to say okay, this
particular DNS server can't be reached,

176
00:08:27.517 --> 00:08:29.269
let me try the next in line.
>> Yes.

177
00:08:29.269 --> 00:08:30.216
>> But there is no next in line.

178
00:08:30.216 --> 00:08:31.438
>> There's no next in line, right.

179
00:08:31.438 --> 00:08:36.117
In fact if I made a mistake on this one,
let's go ahead and

180
00:08:36.117 --> 00:08:40.710
type in a bad IP address, and
we will get that to kick in.

181
00:08:40.710 --> 00:08:44.435
I am gonna open up my browser.
>> While we're shopping can we go to

182
00:08:44.435 --> 00:08:46.736
Zappos.com?
>> Absolutely, let's say Zappos.com.

183
00:08:46.736 --> 00:08:47.823
>> All right, I need some new shoes.

184
00:08:47.823 --> 00:08:49.309
>> Zappos.com.

185
00:08:51.527 --> 00:08:53.166
And uh-oh.
>> [LAUGH]

186
00:08:53.166 --> 00:08:54.374
>> Yeah, it's not looking good for

187
00:08:54.374 --> 00:08:56.230
the home team, is it?
>> No shopping?

188
00:08:56.230 --> 00:08:58.290
It is not going anywhere.

189
00:08:58.290 --> 00:09:00.130
Come on.
>> But that's exactly what you expected to

190
00:09:00.130 --> 00:09:02.630
happen, right?
>> Yes, this is what would happen.

191
00:09:02.630 --> 00:09:07.110
If you can't resolve that name, cuz again
a computer can't connect to zappos.com,

192
00:09:07.110 --> 00:09:08.450
it needs the IP address.

193
00:09:08.450 --> 00:09:12.360
So without DNS it can't convert
the name into an IP address and

194
00:09:12.360 --> 00:09:14.140
you get nowhere, all right.

195
00:09:14.140 --> 00:09:17.794
So let's go back into our
properties talk about.

196
00:09:17.794 --> 00:09:20.510
>> I do know another Google DNS IP but

197
00:09:20.510 --> 00:09:23.138
I think it's 8.8.4.4.

198
00:09:23.138 --> 00:09:24.391
I could be wrong, but
I think that's another.

199
00:09:24.391 --> 00:09:27.940
>> 8.8.4.4, well let's try and see.

200
00:09:27.940 --> 00:09:33.994
So now what I'm doing, right, is I've got
my preferred DNS server 8.8.8.115 but

201
00:09:33.994 --> 00:09:38.432
I also have an alternate DNS server,
8.8.4.4, all right?

202
00:09:38.432 --> 00:09:41.620
Let's see if that helps.

203
00:09:41.620 --> 00:09:44.805
We know the first one is intentionally
wrong so it's not gonna work.

204
00:09:44.805 --> 00:09:47.333
Let's see if I can get to.
>> And

205
00:09:47.333 --> 00:09:51.651
this one could be wrong too but [LAUGH].
>> Zappos.com.

206
00:09:51.651 --> 00:09:54.860
And look at there,
we've made it out to Zappos.

207
00:09:54.860 --> 00:09:58.767
All right, so lets close that and
go back over to my ethernet and

208
00:09:58.767 --> 00:10:01.297
talk about what the heck happened here.

209
00:10:01.297 --> 00:10:06.043
All right, so the way this works is
you're, I listing two, my preferred and

210
00:10:06.043 --> 00:10:07.000
my alternate.

211
00:10:07.000 --> 00:10:09.490
The preferred is the one
it's gonna try first.

212
00:10:09.490 --> 00:10:12.730
And hopefully that will give me
that answer I'm looking for.

213
00:10:12.730 --> 00:10:16.820
[COUGH] If the first one
does not respond and

214
00:10:16.820 --> 00:10:19.900
there is an alternate DNS server
configured, then my server,

215
00:10:19.900 --> 00:10:24.390
my client, will move on and say, all
right, well, 8.8.8.115 is not responding.

216
00:10:24.390 --> 00:10:27.590
Let me try 8.8.4.4, all right.

217
00:10:27.590 --> 00:10:29.480
And if that one's responding, great.

218
00:10:29.480 --> 00:10:32.220
If not,
well I'm out of IP addresses to try.

219
00:10:32.220 --> 00:10:34.600
You don't get to go to Zappos.com.

220
00:10:34.600 --> 00:10:39.280
Here is the key point I want
everybody to take away though.

221
00:10:39.280 --> 00:10:42.070
When I say that we'll use the alternate,

222
00:10:42.070 --> 00:10:45.770
if the preferred DNS server
does not respond, all right?

we'll see that Titus is not in this list.

490
00:26:52.990 --> 00:26:58.067
So if I wanna use this Advanced Sharing,
I've got to assign the share permissions.

491
00:26:58.067 --> 00:27:01.748
But I also have to assign
the matching NTFS permissions,

492
00:27:01.748 --> 00:27:03.530
or whatever I choose to do.

493
00:27:03.530 --> 00:27:05.785
So I wanna make sure you
guys are clear on that.

494
00:27:05.785 --> 00:27:08.311
That if you do the Advanced Sharing,

495
00:27:08.311 --> 00:27:11.742
you are not done when you click Share,
all right?

496
00:27:11.742 --> 00:27:16.762
You still need to set the appropriate NTFS
permissions or check on those as well.

497
00:27:16.762 --> 00:27:22.750
And again, we'll come back around to that
as we get to those NTFS permissions.

498
00:27:22.750 --> 00:27:26.350
All right, I wanna click
Advanced Sharing one more time.

499
00:27:26.350 --> 00:27:30.740
Now that I've shared this out, you look
at this, oops, you look at this name.

500
00:27:30.740 --> 00:27:31.650
What did I just do?

501
00:27:31.650 --> 00:27:33.619
I started a timer, great.
>> [LAUGH]

502
00:27:33.619 --> 00:27:34.850
>> We don't want a timer.

503
00:27:34.850 --> 00:27:37.412
A little keyboard shortcut mishap there.

504
00:27:37.412 --> 00:27:42.393
I'm gonna zoom in, and remember I said
we're gonna leave the name Project Data,

505
00:27:42.393 --> 00:27:45.010
but notice I now have an Add button.

506
00:27:45.010 --> 00:27:47.250
This was grayed out before.

507
00:27:47.250 --> 00:27:53.040
I can come back in and add additional
share names to the same share, all right?

508
00:27:53.040 --> 00:27:58.990
Maybe this used to be known as Project x,
and now it's Project Data.

509
00:27:58.990 --> 00:28:00.920
Some people still remember Project x.

510
00:28:00.920 --> 00:28:08.357
So I can come in here, And
add Project x as a share.

511
00:28:08.357 --> 00:28:12.830
I can even set different permissions
based on what name you use to connect to

512
00:28:12.830 --> 00:28:13.960
the share.

513
00:28:13.960 --> 00:28:18.930
But I'll click OK, and
now it's shared twice in a way, right?

514
00:28:18.930 --> 00:28:21.512
It's shared as Project Data and Project x.

515
00:28:21.512 --> 00:28:22.816
And Cherokee said, you know what,

516
00:28:22.816 --> 00:28:25.522
we really should just call it PD cuz
that's gonna be easier for everyone.

517
00:28:25.522 --> 00:28:28.653
So I can click add, I can do PD,
and I can click OK.

518
00:28:28.653 --> 00:28:30.180
>> So accommodating, Mike.

519
00:28:30.180 --> 00:28:31.745
>> Yeah, thank you, I try to be,

520
00:28:31.745 --> 00:28:33.019
that's what we do in IT.

521
00:28:33.019 --> 00:28:34.094
We try to help our users.

522
00:28:34.094 --> 00:28:36.230
We'll click Apply and OK.

523
00:28:36.230 --> 00:28:41.860
And now you can connect to that
using any one of those methods.

524
00:28:41.860 --> 00:28:42.940
Let's go test that out.

525
00:28:42.940 --> 00:28:45.975
If I go back over to client two.

526
00:28:45.975 --> 00:28:48.190
I think I'm logged in as Titus.

527
00:28:48.190 --> 00:28:50.300
And you know what,
I didn't give Titus permissions.

528
00:28:50.300 --> 00:28:55.069
Let me set the NTFS permissions
real quick so everything will work.

529
00:28:55.069 --> 00:29:03.590
And, again, we'll talk about the NTFS
permissions in a separate episode.

530
00:29:03.590 --> 00:29:07.650
So I'm just gonna give him
Modify permissions there,

531
00:29:07.650 --> 00:29:08.664
just to make that work, right?

532
00:29:10.350 --> 00:29:13.150
So back over to client two.

533
00:29:13.150 --> 00:29:19.870
And Titus comes to his machine, \\client01
and he can connect to Project Data.

534
00:29:19.870 --> 00:29:24.426
So just like using the basic sharing
wizard, the end results are the same,

535
00:29:24.426 --> 00:29:24.940
right?

536
00:29:24.940 --> 00:29:26.631
I can see that he can connect to it.

537
00:29:26.631 --> 00:29:31.732
But I could also do \\client01\pd and

538
00:29:31.732 --> 00:29:35.770
connect to that same folder.

539
00:29:35.770 --> 00:29:42.660
Or I could use the old name,
projectx, and still connect to that.

540
00:29:42.660 --> 00:29:45.230
So the ability to give
a share multiple names is

541
00:29:45.230 --> 00:29:47.400
only available in that
Advanced Sharing wizard.

542
00:29:47.400 --> 00:29:49.850
And you think, well, that's silly.

543
00:29:49.850 --> 00:29:54.370
We've given you one example, like a nice
short name that's easier to remember.

544
00:29:54.370 --> 00:29:59.460
Another thing is, what if people
had mapped drives to that share

545
00:29:59.460 --> 00:30:04.720
under the old name and now you wanna
change the name of that folder?

546
00:30:04.720 --> 00:30:06.870
You can end up breaking things, right?

547
00:30:06.870 --> 00:30:11.659
So if I can share it using multiple names,
I can allow those maps to still continue

548
00:30:11.659 --> 00:30:16.183
to function with a share, even though
I've changed the name of that share.

549
00:30:16.183 --> 00:30:18.823
All right, so
that's a look at the Advanced Sharing.

550
00:30:18.823 --> 00:30:22.040
Again, we've got a lot more to talk
about when it comes to sharing.

551
00:30:22.040 --> 00:30:26.600
And as we bring in NTFS
permissions as well.

552
00:30:26.600 --> 00:30:28.216
But I think it's probably a good place for

553
00:30:28.216 --> 00:30:31.060
us, Cherokee, to stop for this one.
>> Great, thank you so much for

554
00:30:31.060 --> 00:30:31.940
that information, Mike.

555
00:30:31.940 --> 00:30:33.670
And thank you for joining us as well.

556
00:30:33.670 --> 00:30:36.690
But we are gonna come back with
a part three for this topic.

557
00:30:36.690 --> 00:30:37.830
So we're gonna sign out now.

558
00:30:37.830 --> 00:30:40.100
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

559
00:30:40.100 --> 00:30:43.310
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

So different ways that I could make

If you remember from previous

35
00:01:38.610 --> 00:01:41.820
I am gonna fire up PowerShell

Remember what we talked about,

38
00:01:46.850 --> 00:01:49.580
It doesn't change just because
you are using Power Shelf, so

39
00:01:49.580 --> 00:01:51.760
you still need those
administrative rights.

40
00:01:51.760 --> 00:01:57.188
The command is pretty straightforward,
it's gonna be new -SMB share.

41
00:01:57.188 --> 00:01:59.920
All right, new-SMBShare.

Kind of like when we went into the GUI,

00:02:08.900 --> 00:02:12.540
we took a look at some of the advanced
caching options, things like that.

47
00:02:12.540 --> 00:02:14.250

and

00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:19.235
it would behoove you to do
a git-help new-SMBShare or go out to

49
00:02:19.235 --> 00:02:23.490
docs.microsoft.com and take a look at
some of those different parameters.

50
00:02:23.490 --> 00:02:27.990
But I think on the exam it's probably just
gonna be mainly making sure you know,

51
00:02:27.990 --> 00:02:30.600
what command would be used
to create a new share.

00:02:30.600 --> 00:02:33.565

>> Well this is what we're calling it,

55
00:02:37.930 --> 00:02:41.798
So this is like kinda when we're in
the share we said even though the folder's

00:02:41.798 --> 00:02:42.937
name is Project Data.

57
00:02:42.937 --> 00:02:45.588
We could name it PD for short,
like you were talking about,

58
00:02:45.588 --> 00:02:46.873
you know those short names.

59
00:02:46.873 --> 00:02:49.085
>> Yeah, like P Diddy.
>> Yeah, exactly.

60
00:02:49.085 --> 00:02:51.778
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we can name this [LAUGH] whatever we

61
00:02:51.778 --> 00:02:55.988
want, if we wanna name it Cool Hand Luke,
I guess we could do it that.

62
00:02:55.988 --> 00:02:59.660
But remember, we can shorten up
those names, make it easier for

63
00:02:59.660 --> 00:03:03.205
our users to remember,
especially if they're crazy names.

64
00:03:04.255 --> 00:03:05.105
>> Really long ones?

65
00:03:05.105 --> 00:03:09.045
>> Yeah, cryptic names that maybe
include dates, things like that.

66
00:03:09.045 --> 00:03:13.015
Or maybe the share used to be known as
something else, it's now shared out as

67
00:03:13.015 --> 00:03:16.650
a different name, but we wanna use that
old name that people are familiar with.

68
00:03:16.650 --> 00:03:18.160
So the name could be anything.

69
00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:21.614
In fact, the folders name was
Project Data, just to show you,

70
00:03:21.614 --> 00:03:23.253
I'm gonna do PD,all right?

71
00:03:23.253 --> 00:03:27.316
I am putting it in quotes cuz it is
a string, you could use single quotes or

72
00:03:27.316 --> 00:03:28.840
double quotes here.

73
00:03:28.840 --> 00:03:30.617
Really wouldn't make
a difference in this case.

74
00:03:30.617 --> 00:03:33.633
And then -path, and this, Cherokee,

75
00:03:33.633 --> 00:03:39.057
is the actual folder that we're
trying to share, which would be E:\.

76
00:03:39.057 --> 00:03:42.430
It's right on the root project data.

77
00:03:42.430 --> 00:03:43.670
So that's all I need.

78
00:03:43.670 --> 00:03:48.356
What I wanna call the share, and
what I'm actually sharing out, all right?

79
00:03:48.356 --> 00:03:50.230
So we'll hit Enter.

80
00:03:50.230 --> 00:03:51.680
And if everything goes well,

81
00:03:51.680 --> 00:03:57.240
I'll have a new share called PD
that point to e:projectdata.

82
00:03:57.240 --> 00:04:02.388
And now if I go over to another machine,
open up file explorer,

83
00:04:02.388 --> 00:04:09.205
