client01/PD, and there's that share.

84
00:04:09.205 --> 00:04:10.934
>> Pretty cool
>> Yeah very cool, and

85
00:04:10.934 --> 00:04:12.590
very easy to do in the end.

86
00:04:12.590 --> 00:04:17.267
All right, if we take a look at the
properties of that folder we'll see that

87
00:04:17.267 --> 00:04:20.846
it is indeed now shared out
as that app there, all right?

88
00:04:20.846 --> 00:04:26.116
So that's PowerShell, that's how we're
gonna create a share through PowerShell.

89
00:04:26.116 --> 00:04:27.502
All right Cherokee,

90
00:04:27.502 --> 00:04:32.225
the next thing I wanna talk about here
is something known as homegroups.

91
00:04:32.225 --> 00:04:36.346
Homegroups were a pretty
cool thing back in the day,

92
00:04:36.346 --> 00:04:42.540
back in the Windows IX days and maybe
a little bit beyond there getting into XP.

93
00:04:42.540 --> 00:04:44.780
We used to have something
known as work groups, right?

94
00:04:44.780 --> 00:04:47.940
That we could use to network some
computers together that weren't in

95
00:04:47.940 --> 00:04:49.290
a domain environment.

96
00:04:49.290 --> 00:04:53.752
But gave us the ability to kinda access
resources on other machines on that same

97
00:04:53.752 --> 00:04:54.370
network.

98
00:04:54.370 --> 00:04:56.370
But it was kind of a pain.

99
00:04:56.370 --> 00:05:00.630
You had to make sure that each user
had an account on each machine so

100
00:05:00.630 --> 00:05:03.405
that they can access those resources
on the different machines.

101
00:05:03.405 --> 00:05:07.210
Homegroups kinda simplified
that whole process.

102
00:05:07.210 --> 00:05:12.490
It gave you the ability to share
resources amongst my computers

103
00:05:12.490 --> 00:05:17.940
on a local area network without having
to create accounts for everybody.

104
00:05:17.940 --> 00:05:19.570
It creates this homegroup.

105
00:05:19.570 --> 00:05:22.371
And this homegroup then,
when you join the homegroup,

106
00:05:22.371 --> 00:05:26.770
you get access to everything that's being
made available through that homegroup.

107
00:05:26.770 --> 00:05:31.060
>> Okay, so everything that's being made
available, what are you talking here,

108
00:05:31.060 --> 00:05:31.730
like documents?

109
00:05:31.730 --> 00:05:33.200
>> Yeah if you think about your household.

110
00:05:33.200 --> 00:05:35.450
How many of you have household
with more than one computer?

111
00:05:35.450 --> 00:05:40.510
Maybe your spouse and your kids, or
just you have multiple computers.

112
00:05:40.510 --> 00:05:45.074
Like I have my desktop in my office, I
have my laptop that I sit on my couch and

113
00:05:45.074 --> 00:05:48.413
I can't be troubled to get up and
walk into the office.

114
00:05:48.413 --> 00:05:49.447
>> [LAUGH] No, of course not, Mike.

115
00:05:49.447 --> 00:05:51.940
>> To get to that file I need.

116
00:05:51.940 --> 00:05:54.962
I want to be able to get to it from
the couch, it's a lot easier that way.

117
00:05:54.962 --> 00:05:59.288
But you know, I might have pictures that
I want my kids to be able to access, and

118
00:05:59.288 --> 00:06:02.720
this is a way we can do that,
make those resources available.

119
00:06:04.320 --> 00:06:07.506
Before we go any further, I do need
to go ahead and point out, though,

120
00:06:07.506 --> 00:06:10.098
if you started looking at
Microsoft's documentation,

121
00:06:10.098 --> 00:06:12.647
you'll see that with the next
release of Windows 10.

122
00:06:12.647 --> 00:06:17.623
Which at the time of this shooting,
is going to be the Spring Creators, or

123
00:06:17.623 --> 00:06:21.090
1803,it's supposed to be going away.

124
00:06:21.090 --> 00:06:24.517
So by the time you watch this you might,
if you've updated your Windows machine,

125
00:06:24.517 --> 00:06:25.667
not see homegroups at all.

126
00:06:25.667 --> 00:06:27.541
>> I can't find that feature.

127
00:06:27.541 --> 00:06:30.051
[LAUGH]
>> It might not be there and if so

128
00:06:30.051 --> 00:06:31.304
it's by design.

129
00:06:31.304 --> 00:06:32.213
Microsoft is taking the feature away.

130
00:06:32.213 --> 00:06:36.220
We talked about this before the show,
Cherokee.

131
00:06:36.220 --> 00:06:43.141
You said you used to use homegroups at
one point, but then you switched to.

132
00:06:43.141 --> 00:06:45.507
>> In clouds options that I
have available to me now, and

133
00:06:45.507 --> 00:06:48.253
I think you're gonna talk about
that a little bit later yeah?

134
00:06:48.253 --> 00:06:51.012
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah absolutely Microsoft has their

135
00:06:51.012 --> 00:06:55.743
Cloud Services, we'll talk about OneDrive,
and this is where they want users to go.

136
00:06:55.743 --> 00:06:56.287
>> Right.

137
00:06:56.287 --> 00:06:59.498
>> That's what they want users to use,
because it's, one,

138
00:06:59.498 --> 00:07:02.945
it's built into my operating system,
it's very easy.

139
00:07:02.945 --> 00:07:06.515
I don't have to worry about joining
my machines to the homegroup.

140
00:07:06.515 --> 00:07:08.192
All I have to do is email you a link.

141
00:07:08.192 --> 00:07:11.049
And you can access the file that I've
made available through OneDrive and

142
00:07:11.049 --> 00:07:13.182
it's available anywhere
I've got Internet access.

143
00:07:13.182 --> 00:07:15.016
>> Right, as long as they have that
Internet connection, it's super easy.

144
00:07:15.016 --> 00:07:18.182
>> Not just from that homegroup.

145
00:07:18.182 --> 00:07:22.784
It's a much better solution, I guess,
and that's where they're pushing us.

146
00:07:22.784 --> 00:07:24.147
So homegroups is going away.

147
00:07:24.147 --> 00:07:27.286
But it is also an objective

00:07:27.286 --> 00:07:32.340
I want to make sure you're familiar with

You never know how long it takes for these

00:07:37.490 --> 00:07:38.470
So let's take a look at it here.

Couple of things I want to talk about,
homegroups, one, I said.

00:07:42.290 --> 00:07:44.450
I'm gonna go to my start menu and

00:07:44.450 --> 00:07:47.890
I'm just gonna type in home
group to get this started.

00:07:47.890 --> 00:07:49.775
There's a control panel applet.

155

just peachy.
>> All right, but yeah, today we are gonna

14
00:00:35.168 --> 00:00:39.321
be talking about configuring files and

15
00:00:39.321 --> 00:00:43.154
And we are gonna start by looking at EFS.

16
00:00:43.154 --> 00:00:46.036
In no particular order,
it's just the way the objectives come out.

17
00:00:46.036 --> 00:00:48.950
A lot of times, I'll start with
our file and folder permissions.

18
00:00:48.950 --> 00:00:52.588
But I thought, hey, let's just-
>> [CROSSTALK] Live on the edge, Mike.

19
00:00:52.588 --> 00:00:55.803
>> Yeah, let's talk about good old EFS.

20
00:00:55.803 --> 00:00:59.626
So first thing we should do is we
should define that acronym, right?

21
00:00:59.626 --> 00:01:03.010
EFS stands for Encrypting File System.

22
00:01:03.010 --> 00:01:04.630
And it's not a separate file system.

23
00:01:04.630 --> 00:01:08.094
It's actually part of NTFS,
or NT File System or

24
00:01:08.094 --> 00:01:12.662
New Technology File System,
if you go way back to the days of NT.

25
00:01:12.662 --> 00:01:17.067
But EFS, or Encrypting File System,
is part of NTFS.

26
00:01:17.067 --> 00:01:20.747
And what that means to us is it's build
in, it's part of the file system.

27
00:01:20.747 --> 00:01:24.953
You don't have to add anything or
do anything to use EFS, or

28
00:01:24.953 --> 00:01:26.814
Encrypting File System.

29
00:01:26.814 --> 00:01:31.153
And it's used to, you'll never guess,
encrypt files, right?

30
00:01:31.153 --> 00:01:33.710
[LAUGH] That's its name,
Encrypting File System.

31
00:01:33.710 --> 00:01:36.710
It encrypts files, but
let's break that down a little bit more.

32
00:01:36.710 --> 00:01:40.675
When we say it encrypts files,
we're talking about turning that file,

33
00:01:40.675 --> 00:01:44.185
taking a plain text file,
something that's human readable and

34
00:01:44.185 --> 00:01:46.721
running it through
an encryption algorithm.

35
00:01:46.721 --> 00:01:50.942
And encrypting those contents,
turning it into what we call ciphertext,

36
00:01:50.942 --> 00:01:53.224
something that's not human readable.

37
00:01:53.224 --> 00:01:57.780
Something that I would need decryption
information to get back into.

38
00:01:57.780 --> 00:02:02.433
So it is a way to add another layer
of security to our documents, right?

39
00:02:02.433 --> 00:02:06.896
The idea is that without the proper key,
and we'll define what a key is in just

40
00:02:06.896 --> 00:02:11.033
a minute, without the proper key
you're not considered authorized.

41
00:02:11.033 --> 00:02:14.226
And you will not be able to decrypt
the file, therefore open it up and

42
00:02:14.226 --> 00:02:15.770
read its content.

43
00:02:15.770 --> 00:02:20.150
Now we have NTFS permissions that
we can use to control access, but

44
00:02:20.150 --> 00:02:25.330
this is again just another layer
on top of that, all right?

45
00:02:25.330 --> 00:02:29.670
A few key concepts to deal with whether
we need to be familiar with with EFS.

46
00:02:29.670 --> 00:02:32.440
One is that it's file and
folder level encryption.

47
00:02:32.440 --> 00:02:37.310
We can encrypt individual files or
we can encrypt a folder.

48
00:02:37.310 --> 00:02:39.520
Now, a folder is a container object.

49
00:02:39.520 --> 00:02:42.920
It's not really a file, so
when you encrypt a folder,

50
00:02:42.920 --> 00:02:45.450
you're not actually
encrypting the folder itself.

51
00:02:45.450 --> 00:02:49.769
The folder is just, think of a manilla
folder that you would store files in, or

52
00:02:49.769 --> 00:02:52.199
a hanging file folder in your desk, right?

53
00:02:52.199 --> 00:02:55.224
You can't encrypt that file folder itself,
but

54
00:02:55.224 --> 00:02:58.263
what you can do is flag
that folder as encrypted.

55
00:02:58.263 --> 00:03:02.021
And then any files that I put inside
that folder would then automatically

56
00:03:02.021 --> 00:03:02.940
be encrypted.

57
00:03:02.940 --> 00:03:06.360
I don't have to go back and remember,
I need to encrypt this file.

58
00:03:06.360 --> 00:03:07.565
I need to encrypt that file.

59
00:03:07.565 --> 00:03:10.254
I can encrypt the folder itself,
the container, and

60
00:03:10.254 --> 00:03:12.842
then everything in there
would become encrypted.

61
00:03:12.842 --> 00:03:16.833
And another key concept, which'll
make a little more sense as we break

62
00:03:16.833 --> 00:03:20.958
down the encryption process,
is just because I've encrypted a folder,

63
00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.830
doesn't mean Cherokee couldn't
put a file in that folder.

64
00:03:24.830 --> 00:03:28.680
And it would be encrypted
using Cherokee's information.

65
00:03:28.680 --> 00:03:32.460
So just because I encrypted the folder
doesn't mean everything in the folder is

66
00:03:32.460 --> 00:03:35.698
encrypted using my information, that I'm
the only one that can get access to it.

67
00:03:35.698 --> 00:03:39.580
So again, that'll make a little more sense
I think as we go through the process, but

68
00:03:39.580 --> 00:03:42.010
just something to keep in mind.

69
00:03:42.010 --> 00:03:44.400
It's also transparent to the end user,

70
00:03:44.400 --> 00:03:48.350
meaning that once I've encrypted that
file, I don't have to do anything.

71
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:50.070
If I'm the authorized user,

72
00:03:50.070 --> 00:03:52.400
to open that file up I don't
have to do anything special.

73
00:03:52.400 --> 00:03:55.931
I don't have to right-click on it and
decrypt it first or anything like that.

74
00:03:55.931 --> 00:03:58.921
I just access the file
like I normally would.

75
00:03:58.921 --> 00:04:02.520
And all of the decryption and
then encryption at the other end when I'm

76
00:04:02.520 --> 00:04:06.670
done with the file is done transparently
by the file system in the background.

77
00:04:06.670 --> 00:04:08.100
We'll expand on that as well.

78
00:04:10.000 --> 00:04:13.160
Our encryption is done through
something called keys.

79
00:04:13.160 --> 00:04:16.670
We'll talk about those and
how those are done on a per user basis.

80
00:04:16.670 --> 00:04:21.090
At the time of this writing or
this shooting, it was AES-256 or

81
00:04:21.090 --> 00:04:26.170
the advanced encryption standard 256
was what was used to do the encryption.

82
00:04:26.170 --> 00:04:29.870
And it's not available in Home editions.

83
00:04:29.870 --> 00:04:31.540
There's a really good reason for that.

84
00:04:31.540 --> 00:04:33.450
We're gonna show you what that is.

85
00:04:33.450 --> 00:04:36.470
And users can encrypt without
any additional rights.

86
00:04:36.470 --> 00:04:40.170
I don't need to give somebody
permission to encrypt files.

87
00:04:40.170 --> 00:04:44.090
So those are some of the key concepts that
you'll need especially for this exam.

88
00:04:44.090 --> 00:04:48.370
All of which will I think will be more
clear as we go through our converation.

89
00:04:49.540 --> 00:04:51.310
So I thought, Cherokee,
the first thing we ought to do

90
00:04:51.310 --> 00:04:52.580
is encrypt a file.
>> Okay.

91
00:04:52.580 --> 00:04:54.110
>> See what it looks like, right?

92
00:04:54.110 --> 00:04:57.690
So join me here on my screen, and
I have got my Windows 10 desktop.

93
00:04:57.690 --> 00:05:01.750
This is a Enterprise Edition,
but it's not part of a domain.

94
00:05:01.750 --> 00:05:06.050
So this would be like if you had bought
a laptop from one of the big boxes or

95
00:05:06.050 --> 00:05:06.620
somebody.

96
00:05:06.620 --> 00:05:12.025
And it came pre-installed with Windows 10,
most likely Professional, maybe Home.

97
00:05:12.025 --> 00:05:15.127
But remember,
Home doesn't have the encryption features.

98
00:05:15.127 --> 00:05:18.610
Professional does, and Enterprise as well.

99
00:05:18.610 --> 00:05:20.770
So what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna open up File Explorer.

100
00:05:20.770 --> 00:05:22.360
And I'm gonna go over to My Documents.

101
00:05:22.360 --> 00:05:25.910
Actually, I'm gonna make
a new folder on my C drive.

102
00:05:25.910 --> 00:05:33.432
I'm gonna make a new folder,
and I'll call it Project Data.

103
00:05:33.432 --> 00:05:35.875
And in there, I'm gonna make a new file.

104
00:05:38.501 --> 00:05:41.430
And I'm gonna call this new file.

105
00:05:41.430 --> 00:05:47.440
Let's rename this guy to
something like Plans.

106
00:05:47.440 --> 00:05:48.872
That's pretty cool.

107
00:05:48.872 --> 00:05:52.377
[LAUGH]
>> Well when I think about what I

108
00:05:52.377 --> 00:05:54.636
think you're gonna be thinking about,

109
00:05:54.636 --> 00:05:58.567
I usually like to use the example of
our secret plans to rule the world.

110
00:05:58.567 --> 00:05:59.325
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

111
00:05:59.325 --> 00:06:00.222
[LAUGH]
>> So these can be those plans.

112
00:06:00.222 --> 00:06:01.385
>> This can be those secret plans, yeah.

113
00:06:01.385 --> 00:06:02.140
>> [LAUGH]

114
00:06:02.140 --> 00:06:02.674
>> Death Star plans, right?

115
00:06:02.674 --> 00:06:03.214
>> [LAUGH]

116
00:06:03.214 --> 00:06:05.838
>> This is showing you the one weakness to

117
00:06:05.838 --> 00:06:08.480
this multi, anyway.
>> People are gonna know we're

118
00:06:08.480 --> 00:06:09.023
weirdos now.

119
00:06:09.023 --> 00:06:10.560
[LAUGH]
>> I know, we are geeks,

120
00:06:10.560 --> 00:06:13.070
that's why we're in this business, right?

121
00:06:13.070 --> 00:06:17.691
All right, and let me put in here these

122
00:06:17.691 --> 00:06:22.467
are the secret plans to rule the world.

123
00:06:24.925 --> 00:06:28.910
All right, we'll save it, and
we'll close it, all right?

124
00:06:28.910 --> 00:06:31.790
Now, in order for
a user to encrypt a document,

125
00:06:31.790 --> 00:06:34.720
it's actually one of the advanced
attributes of a file.

126
00:06:34.720 --> 00:06:38.990
So I'm gonna right-click on this document,
I'm gonna go to Properties.

127
00:06:40.250 --> 00:06:42.970
And on that Properties tab,
I'm gonna look down here at the bottom,

128
00:06:42.970 --> 00:06:44.210
right on that General tab.

129
00:06:44.210 --> 00:06:46.270
Make sure my zooming tool's working.

130
00:06:46.270 --> 00:06:49.450
My General tab, down here at the bottom,
I've got these Read-only and

131
00:06:49.450 --> 00:06:52.405
Hidden attributes, and
I have the Advanced button.

132
00:06:52.405 --> 00:06:55.990
If I click Advanced,
another little window pops up,

133
00:06:55.990 --> 00:07:01.000
my Advanced attributes, one of which
is Encrypt contents to secure data.

134
00:07:01.000 --> 00:07:02.330
And that's the one we're gonna be using.

135
00:07:02.330 --> 00:07:04.020
But while I'm here, let me just point out,

136
00:07:04.020 --> 00:07:08.830
right above that you'll see,
compress contents to save disk space.

137
00:07:08.830 --> 00:07:11.440
We don't use this anymore nowadays.

138
00:07:11.440 --> 00:07:13.390
It's not part of the objectives.

139
00:07:13.390 --> 00:07:15.730
But I do wanna make note while we're here,

140
00:07:15.730 --> 00:07:19.980
these two advanced attributes
are mutually exclusive.

141
00:07:19.980 --> 00:07:24.270
Even though they are checkmarks,
which most UI etiquette says checkmarks

142
00:07:24.270 --> 00:07:27.770
you can check more than one,
understand that both of these attributes

143
00:07:27.770 --> 00:07:31.340
are properties of the file system and
you can only use one or the other.

144
00:07:31.340 --> 00:07:35.255
If you compress these content to save
space, it'll make the file smaller.

145
00:07:35.255 --> 00:07:38.475
If you turn around to encrypt it,
Windows will encrypt it.

146
00:07:38.475 --> 00:07:39.385
But it'll decompress it.

147
00:07:39.385 --> 00:07:41.305
It will no longer be compressed.

148
00:07:41.305 --> 00:07:44.455
If it's encrypted and you try to
compress it, it will decrypt it.

149
00:07:44.455 --> 00:07:48.325
If you're the authorized user and
try to compress it, you can't do both.

150
00:07:48.325 --> 00:07:51.617
All right, so I'm gonna choose
encrypt contents to secure data.

151
00:07:51.617 --> 00:07:55.707
And I'm gonna click OK, and
I'm gonna zoom back out.

152
00:07:55.707 --> 00:07:57.121
And I'll click OK to this.

153
00:07:57.121 --> 00:08:00.110
And I'm gonna get this warning, right?

154
00:08:00.110 --> 00:08:00.929
Let's take a look at this.

155
00:08:00.929 --> 00:08:04.484
It's telling me that, or
it's asking me, if I wanna

156
00:08:04.484 --> 00:08:09.760
encrypt the folder that the parent
folder and the file or just the file.

157
00:08:09.760 --> 00:08:13.850
The recommended option is to encrypt
the folder as well as the file.

158
00:08:13.850 --> 00:08:17.340
And there's a couple of good reasons for
this.

159
00:08:17.340 --> 00:08:19.140
One, it's easier, right?

160
00:08:19.140 --> 00:08:22.830
As I put files into this folder,
they would automatically be encrypted.

161
00:08:22.830 --> 00:08:25.910
Don't have to worry about remembering or
doing anything like that.

162
00:08:25.910 --> 00:08:29.010
The other thing is something that you
might not be familiar with if you ever

163
00:08:29.010 --> 00:08:32.600
turned on your hidden files and
system files.

164
00:08:32.600 --> 00:08:35.930
When you open up a document,
a text document, a word document,

165
00:08:35.930 --> 00:08:39.870
what have you, a temporary copy
of that file is made, right?

166
00:08:39.870 --> 00:08:43.300
And it stored a temporary copies
in the same place as the original.

167
00:08:43.300 --> 00:08:46.180
If you turn on hidden files,
you'll actually see it.

168
00:08:46.180 --> 00:08:48.970
And the reason is,
as you're making changes to that file,

169
00:08:48.970 --> 00:08:52.020
at the end if you close it and
decide not to save it,

170
00:08:52.020 --> 00:08:55.580
it can just throw the temporary copy away,
the original is still there.

171
00:08:55.580 --> 00:08:57.030
You choose to save your changes,

172
00:08:57.030 --> 00:09:00.810
it's gonna merge that temporary
copy into the original document.

173
00:09:00.810 --> 00:09:05.330
Long story, a long way to get back
around at the fact that if the folder

174
00:09:05.330 --> 00:09:09.860
is not encrypted, just the file is,
then that temporary copy that gets made,

175
00:09:09.860 --> 00:09:12.220
it's actually not encrypted, all right?

176
00:09:12.220 --> 00:09:17.370
And there's a slim chance that somebody
could try to get access to that.

177
00:09:17.370 --> 00:09:18.770
If the folder was encrypted,

178
00:09:18.770 --> 00:09:21.220
even a temporary copy would have
a little bit of protection.

179
00:09:21.220 --> 00:09:23.974
That's the idea anyway.

180
00:09:23.974 --> 00:09:27.135
For this demo, I'm just gonna
start by encrypting, actually,

181
00:09:27.135 --> 00:09:28.460
I'll do the recommended.

182
00:09:28.460 --> 00:09:29.650
We'll say encrypt the file and

183
00:09:29.650 --> 00:09:32.120
it's parent folder.
>> Okay, so what you just explained,

184
00:09:32.120 --> 00:09:35.690
it reminded me, Mike,
about different states of data.

185
00:09:35.690 --> 00:09:38.410
So would you say that EFS
would be applicable for

186
00:09:38.410 --> 00:09:40.834
data at rest?
>> Yes, absolutely,

187
00:09:40.834 --> 00:09:44.674
this is gonna protect data while it's on
the file system, and that's a great point.

188
00:09:44.674 --> 00:09:47.362
We'll talk a little bit more about that,
but

189
00:09:47.362 --> 00:09:50.490
it's only protecting
the data while it's on disk.

190
00:09:50.490 --> 00:09:51.960
It's not protecting what's in memory.

191
00:09:51.960 --> 00:09:55.161
It's not protecting Protecting it if
it's traveling across the network.

192
00:09:55.161 --> 00:09:57.116
Because it's part of the file system,

193
00:09:57.116 --> 00:10:01.262
it doesn't protect anything you move from
the file system, like to a thumb drive,

194
00:10:01.262 --> 00:10:04.281
as an email attachment,

I can't use this one, group or
user name, because I'm not set up for

390
00:19:39.231 --> 00:19:43.525
that in my domain environment,
but I can set a password.

391
00:19:43.525 --> 00:19:45.877
The reason it's asking me for
this, is because,

392
00:19:45.877 --> 00:19:47.623
my private key is part of the export.

393
00:19:47.623 --> 00:19:51.423
If I was just doing the public key,
it wouldn't prompt me for a password,

394
00:19:51.423 --> 00:19:52.235
nobody cares.

395
00:19:52.235 --> 00:19:54.185
Everybody, I want everybody
to have my public key.

396
00:19:54.185 --> 00:19:56.708
That's the whole point,
that's why we call it public.

397
00:19:56.708 --> 00:20:00.589
Private key has to stay private,
I'll click next.

398
00:20:00.589 --> 00:20:05.242
I'll dump this out on my desktop,
just so we can find it.

399
00:20:05.242 --> 00:20:09.411
My backup key.

400
00:20:11.356 --> 00:20:14.115
Next and Finish.

401
00:20:14.115 --> 00:20:19.490
And the export was successful, and I click
OK, and I'm going to close this console.

402
00:20:19.490 --> 00:20:20.960
Now, there's my back up.

403
00:20:20.960 --> 00:20:24.580
Now obviously, my backup doesn't do me
any good sitting here on my desktop.

404
00:20:24.580 --> 00:20:26.915
Cuz if I lose my hard drive,
it would still be gone.

405
00:20:26.915 --> 00:20:27.515
>> Right.

406
00:20:27.515 --> 00:20:30.300
>> So, I would wanna put this on
thumb drive somewhere, and then,

407
00:20:30.300 --> 00:20:31.758
keep that thumb drive very safe.

408
00:20:31.758 --> 00:20:32.402
>> Under lock and key.

409
00:20:32.402 --> 00:20:37.254
>> As Cherokee would say, label it,
maybe lock it up, put it in a safe.

410
00:20:37.254 --> 00:20:39.838
Just make sure you can find it,
because I've done this.

411
00:20:39.838 --> 00:20:45.591
I have played around with EFS at home,
put my key on a thumb drive.

412
00:20:45.591 --> 00:20:48.276
Six months, eight months later,
I'm looking for that thumb drive.

413
00:20:48.276 --> 00:20:49.932
It's been overwritten several times.

414
00:20:49.932 --> 00:20:53.867
The key is gone, and
I lost access to all my encrypted data.

415
00:20:53.867 --> 00:20:55.923
So, learn from my mistakes, all right?

416
00:20:55.923 --> 00:20:59.678
[LAUGH] So definitely would want to
end up putting this on a thumb drive.

417
00:20:59.678 --> 00:21:04.483
Now, if I had lost my certificate,
in fact, let's do this.

418
00:21:04.483 --> 00:21:08.832
Let's go back in here,
and delete a certificate.

419
00:21:10.725 --> 00:21:15.810
And now it's gone, no,
whatever am I going to do?

420
00:21:15.810 --> 00:21:17.272
Let's see if I could open the document.

421
00:21:17.272 --> 00:21:21.398
I know that might be cache right now,
if I have it logged off.

422
00:21:21.398 --> 00:21:25.598
Let's see what he says, yeah, so
I do still have the key right now.

423
00:21:25.598 --> 00:21:31.077
But if I delete the certificate,
logged off, I'd end up losing access.

424
00:21:31.077 --> 00:21:34.285
So, let's say that it did happen or
let's say you move to new machine,

425
00:21:34.285 --> 00:21:35.957
they had to replace your hard drive.

426
00:21:35.957 --> 00:21:38.702
And you had all these encrypted
files up here in a share.

427
00:21:38.702 --> 00:21:42.623
But they've had to replace my hard drive,
I don't have my private key anymore.

428
00:21:42.623 --> 00:21:44.353
Lucky for us we've got a backup.

429
00:21:44.353 --> 00:21:46.115
I'm simply gonna double click on it.

430
00:21:46.115 --> 00:21:48.920
And look,
it brings me right to the import wizard.

431
00:21:48.920 --> 00:21:53.590
I'm gonna import for my current user,
that's me, I'll click Next.

432
00:21:53.590 --> 00:21:56.681
I found the file name,
that's fine, I'll click Next.

433
00:21:56.681 --> 00:22:02.930
I'll enter the super secret password
I used, and I'll click Next.

434
00:22:02.930 --> 00:22:06.385
And I'll put it in the appropriate store,
I'll let it pick, that's fine,

435
00:22:06.385 --> 00:22:07.889
we'll click Next, and Finish.

436
00:22:07.889 --> 00:22:10.044
And the import was successful.

437
00:22:10.044 --> 00:22:14.984
And now, if I go take a look,
hopefully, there it is.

438
00:22:14.984 --> 00:22:18.264
My certificate is back, so,
it's so easy to export.

439
00:22:18.264 --> 00:22:20.254
It's just that most people
don't know to do that, right?

440
00:22:20.254 --> 00:22:22.818
And it's nice now that Windows
at least prompts you for that.

441
00:22:22.818 --> 00:22:23.362
>> Reminds you.

442
00:22:23.362 --> 00:22:24.409
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

443
00:22:24.409 --> 00:22:27.088
>> Yes, but it's something that we've
gotta work with and teach our users.

444
00:22:27.088 --> 00:22:30.936
If you're managing a small shop,
where there isn't a domain controller.

445
00:22:30.936 --> 00:22:33.471
And a built in recovery agent,
this is what you've gotta show them.

446
00:22:33.471 --> 00:22:37.601
Gotta teach them how to back up that key
or you've gotta back it up for them,

447
00:22:37.601 --> 00:22:38.266
all right?

448
00:22:38.266 --> 00:22:41.683
In a domain environment,
if I had lost my certificate,

449
00:22:41.683 --> 00:22:44.607
then I would simply
contact my administrator.

450
00:22:44.607 --> 00:22:47.427
And go through whatever
process was necessary.

451
00:22:47.427 --> 00:22:48.868
But they would get the recovery agent.

452
00:22:48.868 --> 00:22:53.532
Somebody would log on as the recovery
agent, and they would decrypt my files for

453
00:22:53.532 --> 00:22:54.306
me, right?

454
00:22:54.306 --> 00:22:57.413
Then I would get a new key
pair issued to me, and

455
00:22:57.413 --> 00:22:59.896
I would encrypt them all over again.

456
00:22:59.896 --> 00:23:02.769
So, that's the way it would
work in a domain environment.

457
00:23:02.769 --> 00:23:05.666
And that's your key,
I think, wraps up EFS.

458
00:23:05.666 --> 00:23:09.494
We've taken at look at how it works,
what it's made up of,

459
00:23:09.494 --> 00:23:11.575
and how to keep ourselves safe.

460
00:23:11.575 --> 00:23:14.657
If it's in a work group environment,
backing up our keys,

461
00:23:14.657 --> 00:23:16.332
sent it to domain environment.

462
00:23:16.332 --> 00:23:19.653
Making sure we understand who
that recovery agent is, and

463
00:23:19.653 --> 00:23:21.294
how they can recover files.

464
00:23:21.294 --> 00:23:22.369
>> Well thank you Mike for

465
00:23:22.369 --> 00:23:25.833
that in-depth explanation to make
sure that we really understand EFS.

466
00:23:25.833 --> 00:23:30.197
I appreciate that, I also appreciate you
being with us, but for now let's sign out.

467
00:23:30.197 --> 00:23:31.561
I've been your host, Cherokee Booze.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike look at configuring NTFS permissions. They describe the permissions available, and how to assign the permissions to users and groups. They also look at the difference between explicit permissions and inherited permissions.
episodes.title: Configure File and Folder Access Part 3

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITPRO.TV,

2

00:00:51.185 --> 00:00:57.555
The way we secure access to our

20
00:00:57.555 --> 00:01:00.530
And really what it comes down to--

21
00:01:00.530 --> 00:01:05.248
When we talk about security,

22
00:01:05.248 --> 00:01:09.750
confidentiality, integrity and

23
00:01:09.750 --> 00:01:12.238
And when we think about security and

24

00:01:15.923 --> 00:01:19.205

00:01:48.230 --> 00:01:50.750
So we're talking about security and
availability,

37
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:55.640
to making sure that we give
the availability in a secure fashion.

38
00:01:55.640 --> 00:01:56.930
Anyway, enough of that.

39
00:01:56.930 --> 00:02:00.470
Take a look at our track,
we'll go into more detail there.

40
00:02:00.470 --> 00:02:03.872
Here, let's just focus on what we
need to know for the exam, and

41
00:02:03.872 --> 00:02:05.971
that is dealing with NTFS permission.

42
00:02:05.971 --> 00:02:08.700
So, the first thing I wanna talk
about is just square away some terms.

43
00:02:08.700 --> 00:02:13.099
Make sure we're all on the same page,
because these are probably things, that if

44
00:02:13.099 --> 00:02:17.500
you've done this before you're familiar
with it, you understand but on the exam

45
00:02:17.500 --> 00:02:21.880
they might use terms you don't use in
your every day dealings with permissions.

46
00:02:21.880 --> 00:02:23.362
So let's start there.

47
00:02:23.362 --> 00:02:28.394
We're looking at my screen, I'm on my
Windows 10 box, and I'm going to right

48
00:02:28.394 --> 00:02:33.796
click on this folder called Project data,
and I'm going to choose Properties Right,

49
00:02:33.796 --> 00:02:39.100
and on this properties page let me just
zoom in here there is a security tab.

50
00:02:39.100 --> 00:02:42.680
That we call it the security tab,
this is where we add or remove people,

51
00:02:42.680 --> 00:02:47.400
we add entries control levels
of access to a resource.

52
00:02:47.400 --> 00:02:52.470
This is what's known as
the discretionary access control list.

53
00:02:52.470 --> 00:02:57.100
DACL or DACL for short.

54
00:02:57.100 --> 00:03:00.240
>> Not to be confused with cankle.

55
00:03:00.240 --> 00:03:01.710
That's something totally different.

56
00:03:01.710 --> 00:03:04.465
>> That is completely different and
probably not part of this show.

57
00:03:04.465 --> 00:03:07.360
[LAUGH]
>> But this is a DACL or

58
00:03:07.360 --> 00:03:09.290
a discretionary access control list.

59
00:03:09.290 --> 00:03:14.210
So when you go out there and you read, and
you look at command line tools like icacls

60
00:03:14.210 --> 00:03:17.930
or using PowerShell to modify the DACL,
what the heck are they talking about?

61
00:03:17.930 --> 00:03:18.440
>> Right.

62
00:03:18.440 --> 00:03:19.320
>> This is it right here.

63
00:03:19.320 --> 00:03:23.250
We're used to going in the GUI,
and clicking Edit, and adding.

64
00:03:23.250 --> 00:03:25.060
But what this GUI is showing me,

65
00:03:25.060 --> 00:03:30.160
this is the graphical user interface for
the discretionary access control list.

66
00:03:31.240 --> 00:03:34.650
Each one of these lines SYSTEM,
Mike Rodrick,

67
00:03:34.650 --> 00:03:39.260
Administrator, these are known as
an ACE or an access control entry.

68
00:03:39.260 --> 00:03:41.700
And this is how you provide
access to a resource.

69
00:03:41.700 --> 00:03:45.410
You go to the DACL, and
you create a new ACE for somebody or

70
00:03:45.410 --> 00:03:49.040
a group of somebodies that
needs access to the resource.

71
00:03:49.040 --> 00:03:51.880
Keep in mind it doesn't have to be a user,
it could be a computer.

72
00:03:51.880 --> 00:03:54.390
Those are also security identifiers.

73
00:03:54.390 --> 00:03:55.720
We can add those.

74
00:03:55.720 --> 00:03:56.860
Computers can be in groups.

75
00:03:56.860 --> 00:03:59.310
We can add them as well.

76
00:03:59.310 --> 00:04:00.070
Alright.

77
00:04:00.070 --> 00:04:05.990
So DACL, discretionary access control
list, ACE access control entry,

78
00:04:05.990 --> 00:04:11.820
you can also call this an ACL, an access
control list without the D on there.

79
00:04:11.820 --> 00:04:15.950
Technically, with Windows,
we use discretionary acts as control list,

80
00:04:15.950 --> 00:04:19.240
because it's at the discretion
of the creator owner.

81
00:04:19.240 --> 00:04:22.270
If you create a folder,
you right click in Windows Explorer.

82
00:04:22.270 --> 00:04:28.040
New folder, or new file, or you go into
Excel or Word and you create a document.

83
00:04:28.040 --> 00:04:30.770
And you save it on the hard drive,
well you're the creator or

84
00:04:30.770 --> 00:04:33.410
owner of that document resource.

85
00:04:33.410 --> 00:04:37.980
And you actually have full control over
that resource, full control allows you to

86
00:04:37.980 --> 00:04:41.930
modify or choose, who does or
doesn't have access to the resource.

87
00:04:41.930 --> 00:04:47.050
You can modify the access control list,
which means it's at your discretion,

88
00:04:47.050 --> 00:04:48.080
hence the name.

89
00:04:48.080 --> 00:04:53.070
Discretionary access control versus, where
it's at somebody's discretion versus, say,

90
00:04:53.070 --> 00:04:56.300
mandatory access control
where it's predefined

91
00:04:57.310 --> 00:05:01.570
where if you were belong to this rule and
you have access to this resource.

92
00:05:02.670 --> 00:05:08.320
So just a couple terms again,
ACL, DACL and ACE.

93
00:05:08.320 --> 00:05:13.320
We'll also talk about something known as a
system access control list at some point,

94
00:05:13.320 --> 00:05:14.120
or SACL.

95
00:05:14.120 --> 00:05:17.230
It's another list
associated with a resource.

96
00:05:17.230 --> 00:05:20.740
This is how we control auditing for
a particular resource.

97
00:05:20.740 --> 00:05:23.200
We'll take a look at that eventually.

98
00:05:24.980 --> 00:05:28.750
So now we know what this is, let's talk
about the permissions that we have

99
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:31.600
available when we look at
this access control list.

100
00:05:31.600 --> 00:05:35.800
You'll see these are known
as my standard permissions.

101
00:05:35.800 --> 00:05:41.030
Full control, Modify, Read & execute,
List folder contents, Read and Write.

102
00:05:41.030 --> 00:05:44.500
And they're pretty self explanatory,
except for maybe that right one and

103
00:05:44.500 --> 00:05:45.570
that modify one.

104
00:05:45.570 --> 00:05:48.120
The rest of them we can
probably figure out.

105
00:05:48.120 --> 00:05:51.880
Read is gonna give me
the ability to read a document,

106
00:05:51.880 --> 00:05:56.785
or if it's a folder I can list
folder contents as we see here.

107
00:05:56.785 --> 00:05:59.775
That permission wouldn't
be available on a file,

108
00:05:59.775 --> 00:06:02.115
because you wouldn't
have a folder content.

109
00:06:02.115 --> 00:06:07.680
But read allows you to open a document, or
read the contents of a current document.

110
00:06:07.680 --> 00:06:14.543
Write, is gonna let you create
new documents within that folder.

111
00:06:14.543 --> 00:06:16.840
If it's write permissions over a file,

112
00:06:16.840 --> 00:06:20.100
then you would be able
to change that thought.

113
00:06:20.100 --> 00:06:21.356
You'd be able to write to that.

114
00:06:21.356 --> 00:06:24.080
And I'm being very careful
with the words I choose.

115
00:06:24.080 --> 00:06:27.140
I'm trying not to use the word, modify.

116
00:06:27.140 --> 00:06:29.250
Because that's a separate permission.

117
00:06:29.250 --> 00:06:35.960
So write allows me to create new documents
inside a folder, or write to a file.

118
00:06:36.980 --> 00:06:41.220
List folder contents, again in file
explorer or file from the command line,

119
00:06:41.220 --> 00:06:45.330
I can do a DIR and
I can list the contents of that folder.

120
00:06:45.330 --> 00:06:49.550
Read and Execute,
is read plus the ability to execute.

121
00:06:49.550 --> 00:06:55.390
So if it's a .cmd, a .bat, a .exe,
something that needs to be executed or

122
00:06:55.390 --> 00:06:58.430
run, I would need the read and
execute permissions.

123
00:06:58.430 --> 00:07:02.650
If I have read permission but not read and
execute, I can't double click on a .exe

124
00:07:02.650 --> 00:07:06.090
and expect it to actually do
what it's supposed to do.

125
00:07:06.090 --> 00:07:13.040
Modify permission is the ability to delete
objects, that's really what it's adding.

126
00:07:13.040 --> 00:07:16.280
And we'll talk about how these
build in just a second, but

127
00:07:16.280 --> 00:07:21.390
modify gives you the ability to
delete files out of a folder.

128
00:07:21.390 --> 00:07:24.140
Full control,

129
00:07:24.140 --> 00:07:28.630
actually gives you the ability to
change the access control lists.

130
00:07:28.630 --> 00:07:32.680
Modify the permissions,
the owner of a document.

131
00:07:34.050 --> 00:07:36.330
Now let's talk about the ways these build.

132
00:07:36.330 --> 00:07:40.580
All I did was I clicked,
I can't make any changes here.

133
00:07:40.580 --> 00:07:43.720
To change permissions,
you're gonna click Edit, so I click edit.

134
00:07:44.730 --> 00:07:49.800
And that opens up the access control
list again, but now in an editable view.

135
00:07:49.800 --> 00:07:54.118
And I'm gonna add a new entry just so
we can have something to play with.

136
00:07:54.118 --> 00:08:00.095
I'm gonna add the, I think I've got a
group for the directors, I believe, yeah.

137
00:08:00.095 --> 00:08:03.399
So I've got a directors group
here that I'm gonna add.

138
00:08:03.399 --> 00:08:08.470
And I can see or down below I have two
columns and some check marks, all right?

139
00:08:08.470 --> 00:08:13.040
I've got Allow, Deny and then my
check marks next to my permissions.

140
00:08:13.040 --> 00:08:16.830
And I'm gonna uncheck everything because
one of the things that we need to be

141
00:08:16.830 --> 00:08:20.420
familiar with this how these permissions
build on each other if they do.

142
00:08:20.420 --> 00:08:25.210

00:21:21.710 --> 00:21:25.110

00:21:25.110 --> 00:21:30.370
the edutainers over, I can simply

375
00:21:30.370 --> 00:21:33.040

00:21:33.040 --> 00:21:36.050
I didn't have to modify

00:21:36.050 --> 00:21:38.230

378
00:21:38.230 --> 00:21:41.020
add those two new users to that group.

379
00:21:41.020 --> 00:21:44.730
Let's say one of

380
00:21:44.730 --> 00:21:47.473
Maybe they decided they dont
wanna be an edutainer anymore,

381
00:21:47.473 --> 00:21:50.445
they want to go into the other side

00:21:50.445 --> 00:21:54.293
Well, they no longer need the permissions
that were assigned to them over

383
00:21:54.293 --> 00:21:58.904
those resources as an If I used individual
user accounts, now I’m going back and

384
00:21:58.904 --> 00:22:00.553
manually undoing all that.

385
00:22:00.553 --> 00:22:04.950
I’m finding all the places where
that was assigned permissions and

386
00:22:04.950 --> 00:22:07.422
I’m having to remove those permissions.

387
00:22:07.422 --> 00:22:08.932
If I used groups instead,

388
00:22:08.932 --> 00:22:12.227
all I have to do is pull that

389
00:22:12.227 --> 00:22:16.220
Because they got the permissions

390
00:22:16.220 --> 00:22:19.384
As soon as I pulled them out of the group

391
00:22:19.384 --> 00:22:23.100

00:26:53.883 --> 00:26:58.900

1

8
00:00:25.718 --> 00:00:29.167

11

Thanks for having me back,

12

>> Yeah, so permissions,

13

we started taking a look at our NTF
permissions in the last episode.

And if you remember we assigned
the marketing team, or

group I should say, we zoom in,

write permissions over

00:01:44.771 --> 00:01:47.250

40

>> Brother.

>> [LAUGH]
>> That's a good way of putting it.

54
00:02:26.504 --> 00:02:30.649
You notice that the permissions on

55
00:02:30.649 --> 00:02:32.930
the checkmarks are black.

56
00:02:32.930 --> 00:02:36.863
Whereas on the right,
the properties of the Images folder,

57
00:02:36.863 --> 00:02:39.647
the subfolder, the checkmarks are gray.

58
00:02:39.647 --> 00:02:43.720
And it's not just a glitch in

61
00:02:48.785 --> 00:02:53.320

62
00:02:53.320 --> 00:02:58.113

63
00:02:58.113 --> 00:03:02.552
The gray check marks indicate that

64

65
00:03:03.937 --> 00:03:08.158
It might be the direct parent, it might be
two or three levels up, you have no way

66
00:03:08.158 --> 00:03:12.040

indicate inherited permissions.

67
00:03:12.040 --> 00:03:13.708
So if you think about what we did,

68
00:03:13.708 --> 00:03:17.175
we assigned the permissions directly
to the marketing data folder.

69
00:03:17.175 --> 00:03:21.135
I right-clicked on it, pulled up
the properties, went to the security tab,

70
00:03:21.135 --> 00:03:23.550

I assigned those permissions.

71
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:27.456
That's explicitly assigning permissions
over that particular resource,

72
00:03:27.456 --> 00:03:29.505
in this case the marketing data folder.

73
00:03:29.505 --> 00:03:34.172
Then those permissions automatically
inherited down to all the files and

74
00:03:34.172 --> 00:03:39.375
sub-folders and sub-files inside there,
such as the Images folder over here.

75
00:03:39.375 --> 00:03:44.295
And that is why those check marks
are gray, because they are inherited.

76
00:03:44.295 --> 00:03:49.310
So quick easy visual indicator, whether or
not the permissions are inherited,

77
00:03:49.310 --> 00:03:52.052
or whether they're explicitly assigned.

78
00:03:52.052 --> 00:03:56.776
The reason it's important to understand
that difference is because we can change

79
00:03:56.776 --> 00:03:58.220

80
00:03:58.220 --> 00:04:03.378
If I decide I don't wanna give marketing
those read and write permissions anymore,

81
00:04:03.378 --> 00:04:07.910
or maybe I wanna add,
I wanna give marketing modify permissions.

82
00:04:07.910 --> 00:04:10.445
Well I can go and I can,

83
00:04:10.445 --> 00:04:12.920
Well we'll do it this way,
I'm gonna cancel out.

84
00:04:12.920 --> 00:04:16.587
And so the permissions for

85

00:04:21.770 --> 00:04:25.665
And I'm gonna add modify to that,

88
00:04:26.700 --> 00:04:29.426
And I'll go ahead and,

89
00:04:29.426 --> 00:04:35.442
Now I'm gonna go back to Images,
pull up those properties.

90
00:04:35.442 --> 00:04:40.418
Go to Security tab, Marketing, and
notice they now have modified permissions.

91
00:04:40.418 --> 00:04:43.454
So I made a change to the permissions and

92
00:04:43.454 --> 00:04:47.227
the change inherited down
to the child objects.

93
00:04:47.227 --> 00:04:52.528
Well let's say I don't want them to have
modify permissions over the Images folder.

94
00:04:52.528 --> 00:04:55.718
They shouldn't be messing with the images,
somebody made these graphics,

95
00:04:55.718 --> 00:04:59.100
they put them in there,
maybe they're not supposed to be changed.

96
00:04:59.100 --> 00:05:01.631
So I'm gonna take away their
modify permission here.

97
00:05:01.631 --> 00:05:06.722
Well, if I click Edit,
all right, I got a problem.

98
00:05:06.722 --> 00:05:11.128
I look at Marketing and
the check marks are grayed out.

99
00:05:11.128 --> 00:05:12.952
I can't undo that.

100
00:05:12.952 --> 00:05:17.664
You cannot change inherited
permissions in this way.

101
00:05:17.664 --> 00:05:21.410
Once it inherits those permissions,
those are set.

102
00:05:21.410 --> 00:05:26.612
There's three ways you can go about
changing inherited permissions.

103
00:05:26.612 --> 00:05:29.360
One would be what you just saw,

104
00:05:29.360 --> 00:05:34.660
is to modify them wherever
they're explicitly assigned.

105
00:05:34.660 --> 00:05:38.223
I can't change them here because
they're being inherited.

106
00:05:38.223 --> 00:05:42.434
What I can do is go to where
the permissions are being inherited from,

107
00:05:42.434 --> 00:05:44.770
which in this case is Marketing data.

108
00:05:46.450 --> 00:05:47.293
So I can go to that security tab.

109
00:05:47.293 --> 00:05:51.240
And I can click Edit and go to Marketing.

110
00:05:51.240 --> 00:05:53.140
Then I can uncheck modify.

111
00:05:53.140 --> 00:05:57.517
So I can find out where the permissions
were explicitly assigned and

112
00:05:57.517 --> 00:05:59.067
make the change there.

113
00:05:59.067 --> 00:06:01.245
That's one way to change
inherited permissions.

114
00:06:01.245 --> 00:06:03.533

00:26:04.480 --> 00:26:07.780

It isn't just turn it on and say, okay,

So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna

And we looked at these advanced settings,

Auditing is done through he SACL,

That's where we store

something, maybe you access,

91
00:04:44.840 --> 00:04:47.140

92

Just depends on what it

97

So, who is it that I'm trying to audit,

99
00:05:07.810 --> 00:05:09.870
Success, failure, or both.

00:05:09.870 --> 00:05:14.596
All right, now here is another
little gotcha that you've

102
00:05:18.363 --> 00:05:22.951
Which would monitor both success and

episode, when we turned on auditing, I

00:05:28.220 --> 00:05:33.020
If I only did success in the policy,

00:06:59.040 --> 00:07:02.820

00:07:14.490 --> 00:07:19.380

137
00:07:19.380 --> 00:07:20.930
There's no more failed logon events.

138
00:07:22.100 --> 00:07:25.690

139
00:07:25.690 --> 00:07:27.874
Did the person give up and stop trying?

140
00:07:27.874 --> 00:07:31.360
Does somebody walk by, maybe,

141
00:07:31.360 --> 00:07:34.987
Or, did they succeed and
finally guess the right password, and

142
00:07:34.987 --> 00:07:36.408

00:07:36.408 --> 00:07:39.921
I don't know, because I wasn't

144
00:07:39.921 --> 00:07:42.993
So again, a lot of planning

00:07:50.335 --> 00:07:51.810

00:07:51.810 --> 00:07:52.980
>> Enforces that yeah.

150
00:07:52.980 --> 00:07:56.480
>> They tell me, this is what
regulations say we need to audit.

151
00:07:56.480 --> 00:08:00.250
HIPAA says I need to know any time,
anybody touches any of these.

152
00:08:00.250 --> 00:08:01.520
I can go in and make that policy, right?

153
00:08:01.520 --> 00:08:04.150
That's really what, my side affects.

154
00:08:04.150 --> 00:08:08.240
But I do wanna stress that it is
very important to plan this out.

155
00:08:08.240 --> 00:08:08.926
All right, so what am I gonna do?

156
00:08:08.926 --> 00:08:10.710
I'm gonna go ahead and monitor all.

157
00:08:11.760 --> 00:08:15.273
Do I want it to be, again,

159
00:08:19.170 --> 00:08:21.850

As I said earlier,

00:08:25.070 --> 00:08:28.460
But if they're allowed to read,
maybe I don't want to monitor read.

162
00:08:28.460 --> 00:08:32.120
Maybe I just wanna monitor writes or
modifies.

163
00:08:32.120 --> 00:08:34.100
Again, part of the planning process.

164
00:08:34.100 --> 00:08:36.017
I'm gonna do full control just so

165
00:08:36.017 --> 00:08:40.335
I can monitor everything to make this
demo a little bit easier, all right?

166
00:08:40.335 --> 00:08:42.550
Let me zoom back out.

167
00:08:42.550 --> 00:08:44.310
And that's all we're gonna deal with.

168
00:08:44.310 --> 00:08:48.210

if you wanna be a little more granular.

169
00:08:48.210 --> 00:08:50.540
Remember how we talked about

170

00:24:10.735 --> 00:24:14.440
Well, let me go ahead and click OK just
to show you that it should work now.

442
00:24:14.440 --> 00:24:17.130
So I go back over here, I click connect,

443
00:24:17.130 --> 00:24:22.150
I type in lab/mike and
my appropriate password.

444
00:24:22.150 --> 00:24:23.899
And you'll see a bunch of things
went by there really quick.

445
00:24:23.899 --> 00:24:27.439
That was actually it cycling through
all of the different protocols and

446
00:24:27.439 --> 00:24:31.569
determining which one was gonna work, and
then establishing the connection, and

447
00:24:31.569 --> 00:24:33.380
now it says connected.

448
00:24:33.380 --> 00:24:38.480
So if I go down back to my file Explorer,
and I try to go to dco3, you'll see

449
00:24:38.480 --> 00:24:41.350
I get a lot more than what I had cached.
>> Yeah.

450
00:24:41.350 --> 00:24:43.250
>> I can see all those shares that exist

451
00:24:43.250 --> 00:24:45.910
over there on dc3 cuz I'm now connected.

452
00:24:45.910 --> 00:24:48.850
Even though I'm out there at the hotel,
right, in Timbuktu or

453
00:24:48.850 --> 00:24:54.590
wherever, I can still connect to all those
resources on that corporate network.

454
00:24:54.590 --> 00:24:59.091
We take a look at PowerShell again,
and do a little IP config.

455
00:24:59.091 --> 00:25:03.492
There is my IP address I got
from my ISP at the hotel, but

456
00:25:03.492 --> 00:25:07.800
notice that I have a PPP
adapter called work.

457
00:25:07.800 --> 00:25:11.919
And I've got an IP address that's
valid on the corporate network, right?

458
00:25:11.919 --> 00:25:16.210
So this is showing you that I am
connected to that corporate network.

459
00:25:16.210 --> 00:25:19.300
I would receive an IP address from
the corporate network that's valid on

460
00:25:19.300 --> 00:25:23.260
the corporate network and allowing me
to access printers, or file shares, or

461
00:25:23.260 --> 00:25:28.190
whatever it is that I want
to try to access, all right?

462
00:25:28.190 --> 00:25:29.605
All right, so
we've got that we're disconnected.

463
00:25:29.605 --> 00:25:32.845
To disconnect it,
I'm just gonna click Disconnect.

464
00:25:35.470 --> 00:25:36.363
What else do I wanna show you?

465
00:25:36.363 --> 00:25:41.370
Let's go back over to, well, actually,
let me connect one more time.

466
00:25:41.370 --> 00:25:44.840
I wanna show you it remembers it's
got my password there cached.

467
00:25:44.840 --> 00:25:48.110
Cuz I just disconnected, so
I connected again really quick.

468
00:25:48.110 --> 00:25:51.630
I wanna take a look at this window here.

469
00:25:52.750 --> 00:25:54.003
And I wanna show you this, right?

470
00:25:54.003 --> 00:25:56.808
So now, you'll see it's lit up,
it's not grade out, and

471
00:25:56.808 --> 00:25:59.523
that's because it's connected,
it's established.

472
00:25:59.523 --> 00:26:01.260
Notice the IP is disconnected, right?

473
00:26:01.260 --> 00:26:02.997
That's the other one we haven't used yet.

474
00:26:02.997 --> 00:26:05.765
Right below here,
WAN miniport, PPTP right?

475
00:26:07.095 --> 00:26:09.635
So it cycled through IKE, it didn't work.

476
00:26:09.635 --> 00:26:11.775
It tried SSTP, it didn't work.

477
00:26:11.775 --> 00:26:14.185
It tried L2TP, it didn't work.

478
00:26:14.185 --> 00:26:18.585
It tried PPTP, it worked, and
it established that connection, right?

479
00:26:18.585 --> 00:26:23.683
So that's Windows 10 cycling through,
trying the protocols strongest to weakest

480
00:26:23.683 --> 00:26:29.260
until if finds one that works, and then it
establishes that connection, all right?

481
00:26:29.260 --> 00:26:31.225
The other icon I've got over here,

482
00:26:31.225 --> 00:26:35.190
let's disconnect from that one,
this one is setup to use IKE.

483
00:26:35.190 --> 00:26:42.510
If we look at the profile for
that It's not set to automatic, right?

484
00:26:42.510 --> 00:26:46.650
I went in here and
hit the drop-down list and shows IKEv2.

485
00:26:46.650 --> 00:26:49.930
If your company is only
accepting a single protocol,

486
00:26:49.930 --> 00:26:53.410
there's really no need to force Windows
to cycle through all of them, right?

487
00:26:53.410 --> 00:26:57.976
If you're SSTP and you know that, set it
to SSTP, don't leave it on automatic,

488
00:26:57.976 --> 00:27:01.422
that way you can establish
the connection that much faster.

489
00:27:01.422 --> 00:27:02.480
Or if it's PPTP, right?

490
00:27:02.480 --> 00:27:05.850
Go ahead and choose PPTP if you want.

491
00:27:05.850 --> 00:27:08.490
I also set this to use
machine certificates,

492
00:27:08.490 --> 00:27:10.500
again IKEv2 user certificates.

493
00:27:10.500 --> 00:27:14.050
I'm trying to think if there's
anything else I wanna show you.

494
00:27:14.050 --> 00:27:16.770
This is that mobility option, so

495
00:27:16.770 --> 00:27:20.890
this what gives me the ability
to do the VPN reconnect and

496
00:27:20.890 --> 00:27:25.940
use that mobi IEK, or mobIKE, that we
are talking about earlier, all right?

497
00:27:25.940 --> 00:27:26.800
So we close out of that.

498
00:27:26.800 --> 00:27:27.870
Let me zoom out.

499
00:27:27.870 --> 00:27:29.790
I can connect from here as well.

500
00:27:29.790 --> 00:27:30.790
But it's kinda weird,

501
00:27:30.790 --> 00:27:34.200
cuz if I double-click on that,
it just takes me back over the screen.

502
00:27:34.200 --> 00:27:37.490
And here, I can click Connect and
I'm connected.

503
00:27:37.490 --> 00:27:40.740
Didn't ask me for password because
it's using certificates, right?

504
00:27:40.740 --> 00:27:43.520
My machine, my laptop,
is issued a certificate.

505
00:27:43.520 --> 00:27:47.130
That's what's being authenticated
as it establishes that connection.

506
00:27:47.130 --> 00:27:47.900
Again, same thing.

507
00:27:47.900 --> 00:27:50.292
If I go back over here, DCO3,

508
00:27:50.292 --> 00:27:55.644
I should see all of the shares that
are available over there on DCO3.

509
00:27:55.644 --> 00:27:58.590
So I've establish that VPA connection.

510
00:27:58.590 --> 00:28:04.220
If we go back, we'll see that this
one is using IKEv2, all right?

511
00:28:05.910 --> 00:28:09.840
All right, and then, let me go ahead and
disconnect that one.

512
00:28:13.260 --> 00:28:15.470
What else do we need to cover here?

513
00:28:15.470 --> 00:28:18.090
I know we're getting a little short
on time, so why don't we stop there.

514
00:28:18.090 --> 00:28:20.560
I think we've seen,
over the last couple episodes,

515
00:28:20.560 --> 00:28:23.890
we've talked about what a VPN is,
why we use them.

516
00:28:23.890 --> 00:28:27.110
We've seen all of the protocols
that Windows 10 supports for

517
00:28:27.110 --> 00:28:28.860
creating the VPN connection.

518
00:28:28.860 --> 00:28:31.330
And now,
we've seen a couple connections created

519
00:28:32.700 --> 00:28:35.300
and established.
>> Great, so we were able to see

520
00:28:35.300 --> 00:28:39.410
everything that we talked about in that
part one go into action here in this show.

521
00:28:39.410 --> 00:28:40.910
But for now, let's sign out.

522
00:28:40.910 --> 00:28:43.260
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

523
00:28:43.260 --> 00:28:45.011
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

524
00:28:45.011 --> 00:28:49.120
[MUSIC]

525
00:28:49.120 --> 00:28:54.913
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description:
In this episode, Cherokee and Mike configure system recovery. They begin  
by creating a recovery drive. Then they look at how to configure and use system  
restore points.
episodes.title: Configure System Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:01.190
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.190 --> 00:00:03.693
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.693 --> 00:00:05.302
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.302 --> 00:00:08.322
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.322 --> 00:00:11.750
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.750 --> 00:00:14.351
>> Welcome, everyone,
to your Configure Windows Devices series.

7
00:00:14.351 --> 00:00:16.952
Studying up for that 70-697 exam.

8
00:00:16.952 --> 00:00:18.589
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

9
00:00:18.589 --> 00:00:23.403
In this episode we'll be taking a look at,
well, configuring recovery options.

10
00:00:23.403 --> 00:00:26.174
And with us today we have Mr.
Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:26.174 --> 00:00:26.820
How's it going today, Mike?

12
00:00:26.820 --> 00:00:28.388
>> It's going great, Cherokee,
thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:28.388 --> 00:00:31.135
Excited, as always, to be talking to
everybody out there about Windows 10.

14
00:00:31.135 --> 00:00:35.518
And, yeah, we're gonna be looking at
our good old recovery options, right?

15
00:00:35.518 --> 00:00:39.021
What happens when things start
to go wrong, how do I get back?

16
00:00:39.021 --> 00:00:40.739
How do I keep my system up and running?

17
00:00:40.739 --> 00:00:44.769
>> Well that sounds like a great thing
to know, and especially now instead of

18
00:00:44.769 --> 00:00:48.289
waiting until after something
catastrophic happens, right?

19
00:00:48.289 --> 00:00:48.978
>> That's right, yes.

20
00:00:48.978 --> 00:00:53.363
Best to know all of your options and
plan ahead for things like this, right?

21
00:00:53.363 --> 00:00:54.884
All right, plus,
we've gotta get ready for the exam.

22
00:00:54.884 --> 00:00:57.788
So we need to know what
these different options are,

23
00:00:57.788 --> 00:01:00.831
which ones come into play at what time,
kind of thing.

24
00:01:00.831 --> 00:01:02.372
What's my best method?

25
00:01:02.372 --> 00:01:05.290
So we're gonna go over
a few different ones.

26
00:01:05.290 --> 00:01:08.369
I don't have them in really
any particular order,

27
00:01:08.369 --> 00:01:11.532
just going according to
the Microsoft objectives.

28
00:01:11.532 --> 00:01:14.990
So we'll kinda talk about each one,
and say when you might be using this.

29
00:01:14.990 --> 00:01:18.325
Or what the consequences, right,
of using this particular method would be.

30
00:01:18.325 --> 00:01:22.820
And we're gonna start with
configuring a recovery drive.

31
00:01:22.820 --> 00:01:27.609
Now this is one, the idea behind a
recovery drive if I've got a system that I

32
00:01:27.609 --> 00:01:31.500
cannot boot successfully,
if I can't get into the system.

33
00:01:31.500 --> 00:01:33.440
Then how do I try to fix it, right?

34
00:01:33.440 --> 00:01:37.020
How do I get into that system and
attempt to repair it so

35
00:01:37.020 --> 00:01:41.180
that I can get back to using that laptop,
that desktop, whatever it is?

36
00:01:41.180 --> 00:01:44.890
And a recovery drive is one way
that we can boot the system and

37
00:01:44.890 --> 00:01:46.170
attempt to repair it.

38
00:01:46.170 --> 00:01:50.464
Because what we're gonna end up doing
is putting all of my sys startup files,

39
00:01:50.464 --> 00:01:54.508
everything I'm gonna to boot that
system on a piece of removable media.

40
00:01:54.508 --> 00:01:59.070
Whether that's a DVD or a thumb drive,
or a USB based hard drive, or

41
00:01:59.070 --> 00:02:00.860
something like that.

42
00:02:00.860 --> 00:02:05.950
Some type of external, removable media,
and we can use that to boot our system.

43
00:02:05.950 --> 00:02:09.980
So now our computer is no longer relying
on those system files that are located

44
00:02:09.980 --> 00:02:12.584
on the hard drive that might
have become corrupt or

45
00:02:12.584 --> 00:02:14.820
removed or something has happened.

46
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:15.763
That's the idea.

47
00:02:15.763 --> 00:02:19.280
And this is something that you
wanna be proactive with, right?

48
00:02:19.280 --> 00:02:23.423
It's not gonna do me any good if my
system won't boot and I think wow,

49
00:02:23.423 --> 00:02:25.361
I need to make a recovery drive.

50
00:02:25.361 --> 00:02:27.295
Well it's gonna be a little too
late because you can't get into

51
00:02:27.295 --> 00:02:27.960
the system, right?

52
00:02:27.960 --> 00:02:30.520
You need to get in here to
make that recovery drive.

53
00:02:30.520 --> 00:02:33.660
I guess you could go to another system and
create a recovery drive,

54
00:02:33.660 --> 00:02:35.140
but why not be proactive?

55
00:02:35.140 --> 00:02:37.281
Why not prepare for this kind of thing?

56
00:02:37.281 --> 00:02:39.110
And it's easy, it's really easy to do.

57
00:02:39.110 --> 00:02:40.860
The only thing you're gonna
need is a thumb drive or

58
00:02:40.860 --> 00:02:42.200
some type of external media.

59
00:02:44.010 --> 00:02:48.355
Microsoft or Windows 10 has a wizard
built in that'll allow me to create this.

60
00:02:48.355 --> 00:02:51.151
So I'm gonna show you right now, so
let's take a look at my screen here.

61
00:02:51.151 --> 00:02:54.587
I'm simply gonna go to my Start menu and
I'm gonna type in,

62
00:02:54.587 --> 00:02:56.735
you could type in create a recovery.

63
00:02:56.735 --> 00:03:00.400
Or as you can see here,
I just started typing the word recovery.

64
00:03:00.400 --> 00:03:02.575
And I've got a few options up here.

65
00:03:02.575 --> 00:03:06.170
Recovery options, we'll take a look at
it in a minute, that's something else.

66
00:03:06.170 --> 00:03:10.019
Create a recovery drive, however,
that's the one I want, right?

67
00:03:10.019 --> 00:03:15.158
So we're gonna select that and
click Yes to the good old UAC, all right?

68
00:03:15.158 --> 00:03:20.275
Now this is one, there really isn't
a way to get to it through the settings.

69
00:03:20.275 --> 00:03:23.440
You do need to just search for
it on your Start menu there.

70
00:03:24.950 --> 00:03:27.820
I believe anyway, and
so here is the wizard.

71
00:03:27.820 --> 00:03:29.831
Create a recovery drive.

72
00:03:29.831 --> 00:03:33.971
Even if your PC can't start you can
use a recovery drive to reset it or

73
00:03:33.971 --> 00:03:36.320
troubleshoot problems, all right?

74
00:03:36.320 --> 00:03:37.873
So this is the wizard.

75
00:03:37.873 --> 00:03:40.890
And below that,
let me gonna zoom back in here.

76
00:03:40.890 --> 00:03:44.201
I've got a checkmark here, back up
system files to the recovery drive.

77
00:03:44.201 --> 00:03:46.340
And this, again,
this is the important part.

78
00:03:46.340 --> 00:03:51.201
This is what we want to be able to get
in here, and start this machine, and

79
00:03:51.201 --> 00:03:52.497
troubleshoot it.

80
00:03:52.497 --> 00:03:54.340
So I'm simply gonna click Next.

81
00:03:56.903 --> 00:03:59.260
And then we're gonna wait and
what it's gonna to do is it's gonna look.

82
00:03:59.260 --> 00:04:01.312
I need to have my, I should have told you,

83
00:04:01.312 --> 00:04:03.847
I need my removable media
plugged in at this point.

84
00:04:03.847 --> 00:04:06.535
So I already had my thumb
drive in the machine.

85
00:04:06.535 --> 00:04:10.485
And now it's scanning to see what drives
or removable media I have available.

86
00:04:10.485 --> 00:04:14.537
And it should present me with
a list that I can choose from.

87
00:04:14.537 --> 00:04:17.836
>> Okay, Mike, so if I would have
not had that checkbox checked,

88
00:04:17.836 --> 00:04:20.779
am I just gonna be backing up
any kind of personal files?

89
00:04:20.779 --> 00:04:23.253
Or what is involved with that?

90
00:04:23.253 --> 00:04:26.113
>> [LAUGH] I'm not exactly sure,
to be honest with you.

91
00:04:26.113 --> 00:04:27.880
It's not gonna back up
your personal files.

92
00:04:27.880 --> 00:04:31.465
It will give you the ability
to start the system up.

93
00:04:31.465 --> 00:04:35.204
It's basically creating kind
of a WinPE type environment,

94
00:04:35.204 --> 00:04:37.780
or I should say a WinRE type environment.

95
00:04:37.780 --> 00:04:40.312
>> Okay, to just at least,
if my system's not even booting,

96
00:04:40.312 --> 00:04:43.669
give it a little bit of a kickstart there
to let me access some of those options.

97
00:04:43.669 --> 00:04:45.080
>> Yep, exactly.
So we'll wait and

98
00:04:45.080 --> 00:04:48.280
we'll let this thing whir and
grind for just a second.

99
00:04:48.280 --> 00:04:50.597
I just wanted to show you this
next step where we pick the drive.

100
00:04:50.597 --> 00:04:55.520
I'm not gonna actually finish the process
because it takes a little while.

101
00:04:55.520 --> 00:04:59.939
Even on USB 3 this can take
several minutes or longer,

102
00:04:59.939 --> 00:05:02.256
30 minutes [LAUGH] or more.

103
00:05:02.256 --> 00:05:05.656
[LAUGH] If you were with us the other
day when we were doing some recording,

104
00:05:05.656 --> 00:05:07.120
we found that out the hard way.

105
00:05:07.120 --> 00:05:09.564
So I'll show you the process.

106
00:05:09.564 --> 00:05:13.565
We'll get it started and then I've got
another drive that's already finished.

107
00:05:13.565 --> 00:05:17.520
And I'll show you how to use that
recovery drive once it gets created.

108
00:05:17.520 --> 00:05:21.080
So again, slowly but
surely scanning my system.

109
00:05:21.080 --> 00:05:25.226
It's odd that this takes so long to-
>> And I was gonna ask, Mike,

110
00:05:25.226 --> 00:05:29.442
when it comes to selecting a drive, is
there anything that we should be aware of,

111
00:05:29.442 --> 00:05:30.259
size or speed?

112
00:05:30.259 --> 00:05:31.870
>> Yeah, size is the main thing, right?

113
00:05:31.870 --> 00:05:34.925
Just to make sure that we've got
enough room on that thumb drive.

114
00:05:34.925 --> 00:05:38.010
I've seen a couple of
different requirements.

115
00:05:38.010 --> 00:05:40.705
I know, I think there's wizard,
in fact, yeah, we just finished so

116
00:05:40.705 --> 00:05:42.135
let's take a look at my screen here.

117
00:05:42.135 --> 00:05:43.830
You can see it says 8 GB.

118
00:05:43.830 --> 00:05:46.478
The drive must be able to
hold at least 8 GB and

119
00:05:46.478 --> 00:05:48.929
everything on the drive will be deleted.

120
00:05:48.929 --> 00:05:53.140
I've see in docs.microsoft.com
where they've quoted it at 16 GB.

121
00:05:53.140 --> 00:05:54.888
I would say the more the merrier, right?

122
00:05:54.888 --> 00:05:57.770
The more space you've got,
probably the better.

123
00:05:57.770 --> 00:05:59.476
Speed wise, the faster the better.

124
00:05:59.476 --> 00:06:02.953
Again, you could still do it with USB 2.0.

125
00:06:02.953 --> 00:06:07.787
3.0 is just gonna make this initial
copy process a little bit faster.

126
00:06:07.787 --> 00:06:09.345
>> I'll take some coffee, too.

127
00:06:09.345 --> 00:06:10.044
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, me too.
>> [LAUGH]

128
00:06:10.044 --> 00:06:12.274
>> But if you only have USB 2.0,

129
00:06:12.274 --> 00:06:14.580
then by all means use that.

130
00:06:14.580 --> 00:06:18.720
And again, I think you had asked me
earlier if it backs up system files,

131
00:06:18.720 --> 00:06:19.893
just to reiterate.

132
00:06:19.893 --> 00:06:23.779
Basically what's gonna happen is it's
gonna copy all the recovery utilities to

133
00:06:23.779 --> 00:06:24.993
this removable media.

134
00:06:24.993 --> 00:06:26.783
>> Nice.
>> So all of those things that I can get

135
00:06:26.783 --> 00:06:29.303
to from my advanced boot
options in Windows 10,

136
00:06:29.303 --> 00:06:31.970
It moves those utilities
to the thumb drive.

137
00:06:31.970 --> 00:06:36.712
And if I check that checkmark, like we
did, it also copies all of my system

138
00:06:36.712 --> 00:06:40.934
files so that it can attempt to
repair my installation if need be.

139
00:06:40.934 --> 00:06:45.160
But it doesn't do anything like capture my
